questions.text: All of the following are derived from marked structure except
questions.solution:
The arrow marked structure is somites.

Option wise explanation:

Somites:

  • The paraxial mesoderm is a thick longitudinal column of mesodermal cells that lies on each side of notochord and developing neural tube.
  • The paraxial mesoderm undergoes segmentation and gets organised into segments known as somites (somatomere).

Each somites is divided into 3 parts:

  • Medial part : called Sclerotome: forms vertebra and ribs (axial skeleton)
  • Middle part : called Myotome : forms skeletal muscles.
  • Lateral part : called Dermatome : forms dermis of skin.

Option A, B & D are derivatives from Somites.

Option C : Kidney is developed from intermediate mesoderm.

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology, Vishram Singh, Third edition, Page no 71.

questions.text: What is the action of marked muscle in the given image?
questions.solution:
The marked muscle in given image is Flexor carpi ulnaris.

Origin - medial epicondyle, olecranon and posterior portions of ulna

Insertion - pisiform, hook of hamate and base of 5th metacarpal bone

Action - flexion and adduction of wrist

Option wise explanation:

Option B : Flexion and abduction of wrist : by Flexor carpi radialis.

Option C : Extension and adduction of wrist : Extensor carpi ulnaris.

Option D : Extension and abduction of wrist : Extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis.

Reference: Human Anatomy, B D Chaurasia, Volume 1, 9th edition, Page No 120.

questions.text: What is the active principle of the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Seeds of Semecarpus anacardium, and its active principles are bhilawanol and semicarpol.

  • Common names are marking nut, bhilwan, bibva, and oriental cashew.
  • The image shows black, heart-shaped seeds with hard rinds that identify them as seeds of S. anacardium. Within the fruit is a thick fleshy pericarp that yields the active principle, which is a brown oily resinous fluid called bhilawanol.
  • The juice when applied locally to the skin produces irritation, painful blisters, itching, and eczematous eruption. The seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise.
  • Symptoms such as pain, fever, and painful passage of brownish urine may be seen.

Other Options:

Option A - Abrin - Also known as gunchi, rati, sui; resembles viper/snake bite.

Option C - Calotropin - It is also known as akar and madar; Active principle is uscharin and calotoxin.

Option D - Ricin - It is a toxalbumin in Ricinus communis, also known as arandi.

It is a biological warfare agent (Category B)

KEY TAKEAWAY: Active principle of Semecarpus anacardium is bhilwanol.

CLINICAL RELEVANCE: Medicolegal importance is the use of the juice by malingerers to fabricate wounds. Instilled in the eyes it can cause conjunctivitis or ophthalmia due to its local irritant effect.

TAGLINE: EASY

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 556

questions.text: A 45-year-old psychiatric patient consumed some liquid from a bottle accidentally. Clinical examination shows a peculiar rash as shown in the image. What is the likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic boiled lobster appearance of Boric acid poisoning.

  • It represents generalized desquamation and erythema.
  • Rashes are seen commonly in palms, soles, and buttocks.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oxalic acid - Typically presents with hypocalcemia; known as acid of sugar/salt of sorrel.

Option B - Hydrochloric acid - Also known as muriatic acid, it is a less corrosive acid hence perforation of stomach, corrosion of skin are rare.

Option-D - Carbolic acid.

TIPS AND TRICK - 3 C's

  • Constriction of pupil
  • Deposition in cartilage-ochronosis
  • Causes Carboluria-dark green colored urine

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The characteristic boiled lobster appearance of Boric acid poisoning.

TAGLINE: MODERATE

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 534

questions.text: A 45 years old male patient presents to the hospital with asymptomatic varicose veins, whose image is given below. Which CEAP classification does the patient fall under?
questions.solution:
CEAP classification of chronic lower extremity venous disease

  • The descriptive CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification for chronic venous disorders is widely utilised.

For clinical classification:

  • C0: no signs of venous disease;
  • C1: telangiectasia or reticular veins;
  • C2: varicose veins;
  • C3: oedema;
  • C4a: pigmentation or eczema;
  • C4b: LDS or atrophie blanche;
  • C4c Corona phlebectatica
  • C5: healed venous ulcer;
  • C6: active venous ulcer.

Clinical class can be further characterised as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r.

For aetiological classification:

  • Ec: congenital;
  • Ep: primary;
  • Es: secondary (post-thrombotic);
  • En: no venous cause identified.

For anatomical classification:

  • As: superficial veins;
  • Ap: perforator veins;
  • Ad: deep veins;
  • An: no venous location identified.

For pathophysiological classification:

  • Pr: reflux;
  • Po: obstruction;
  • Pr,o: reflux and obstruction;
  • Pn: no venous pathophysiology identifiable.

Option A. C6: Correct. C6 indicates active venous ulcers.

Option B. C5: Incorrect. C5 refers to healed venous ulcers.

Option C. C4b: Incorrect. LDS or atrophie blanch.

Option D. C4a: Incorrect. pigmentation or eczema.

Key points: According to the CEAP classification, asymptomatic varicose veins fall under C2.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of surgery 28th edition, part 10, chapter 62, page no 1030.

choices.text: Image shows on pump coronary bypass.

questions.text: Intra operative photograph of cardiac surgery has been shown below. The false statement regarding this image is....
questions.solution:
• CABG without the use of CPB is gaining popularity and may be combined with a minimally invasive approach or carried out through a conventional sternotomy. It avoids the potential physiological stress associated with CPB and, to some extent, the aortic manipulation that can lead to neurological injury through atherosclerotic embolisation. Since the introduction of cardiac stabilising devices such as the Octopus®, off-pump coronary artery bypass (OPCAB) grafting has become widespread in the UK and around the world.

Explanation:

Option A. Image shows off pump coronary bypass.

Option B,C,D are correct.

Reference: Bailey and love's Short Practice of surgery, 28th edition, chapter 59, page 953.

questions.text: A full-term infant develops cyanosis, tachypnea, and a sharp drop in oxygen saturation within the first 30 minutes of birth. On examination, she has normal heart sounds, normal liver edge, and oxygen saturation in the low 60s. When placed on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and 100% oxygen, her oxygen saturation remains in the low 70s. A chest X-ray is performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This patient's clinical findings and "egg on a string" appearance of the heart are characteristics of transposition of the great arteries. In this congenital heart defect, the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle. This results in deoxygenated venous blood flowing back to the systemic circulation while oxygenated pulmonary venous blood flows back to the lungs.
  • Patients are typically presented with Cyanosis in the 1 day of life, acute management includes prostaglandin E1 or/and a balloon atrial septostomy to expand the ductus arteriosus and facilitate inter-circulatory mixing. Once the patient is stabilized, corrective surgery should be performed as early as possible.

Option C : Patients of Tetralogy of Fallot presents after 2-4 weeks of life with cyanosis and respiratory distress.

Option D : Hypoplastic left heart patients presents with cardiogenic shock and pallor. Cyanosis is absent or mild.

Option A : Ventricular septal defect is acyanotic disease, hence ruled out.

Reference: Park's Pediatric Cardiology, 6th ed, pg. 209

choices.text: Combination therapy with Zinc and D-penicillamine
Combination therapy with Zinc and Ammonium tetrathiomolybdate

questions.text: A 12-year-old child has hepatic illness. On ophthalmological examination following finding is seen. He also has tendency to forget common things of daily activities. Which of the following is not the treatment option for the child?
questions.solution:
• The image is suggestive of Keyser Fleischer ring. Also, the child has hepatic illness and dementia. These findings are suggestive of Wilson disease.

Mnemonic for clinical features of Wilson disease: ABCD

A - Asterixis, Anemia (Coombs negative)

B - Basal ganglia lesion - Parkinson features in young

C - Copper deposition, Cirrhosis, Corneal deposits (KF ring), Choreoathetosis

D - Dementia, Dystonia, Depression

Treatment options:

  • Chelation therapy
    • D-penicillamine - never combined with Zinc
    • Trientine
    • Ammonium Tetrathiomolybdate - most useful in CNS involvement
  • Zinc
    • reduces GI absorption of copper, as an adjuvant therapy
    • useful in CNS disease
  • Liver transplant - definitive therapy in fulminant hepatic failure or cirrhosis.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed, pg. 1939

questions.text: 10-year old female presented with itchy violaceous papules over bilateral upper and lower limb since 15 days. What would be treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The case given here has multiple Purple, Polygonal, Plane topped (flat), Prutitic Papules with acute onset suggestive of acute eruptive lichen planus. In this case, systemic corticosteroid along with topical steroids are needed. ___(Option B)

In chronic case with few lesions only topical steroids are required. (Option A)

Acitretin is used for extensive hypertrophic Lichen planus (Option D)

Antihistaminics are prescribed for symptomatic treatment. (Option C)

Tag: Management of Lichen planus

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no. 37.20

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with painful genital lesions for 2 days. The lesions are fluid-filled and have been recurrent with similar episodes in the past. On examination, there are multiple superficial erosions with polycyclic margins over the glans. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Herpes Genitalis:

  • Cause: Herpes simplex virus types 1 and 2.
  • Presentation: Multiple clear fluid-filled vesicles that rupture to form painful, superficial erosions with polycyclic margins.
  • History: Recurrent lesions are typical.
  • Treatment: Acyclovir 400 mg TDS for 7 days.

Option A: Chancroid:

  • Cause: Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • Presentation: Painful genital ulcers and swollen inguinal lymph nodes (bubo). Gram stain shows a "school of fish" appearance.
  • Key Difference: Chancroid ulcers are generally not fluid-filled and are not polycyclic.

Option B: Lymphogranuloma Venereum (LGV):

  • Cause: Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3.
  • Stages:
    • Primary: Painless genital ulcer or papule.
    • Secondary: Tender inguinal or femoral lymphadenopathy (Bubo).
    • Late: Strictures, fibrosis, fistulae in the anogenital area.
  • Key Difference: LGV typically presents with a painless ulcer and significant lymphadenopathy, not fluid-filled lesions.

OptionC: Primary Syphilis:

  • Cause: Treponema pallidum.
  • Presentation: Solitary, non-tender genital ulcer (chancre) with a well-defined, indurated, hard margin. Lymphadenopathy is shotty (non-tender).
  • Key Difference: The chancre is indurated and not fluid-filled, with a hard edge, unlike the painful, fluid-filled lesions of herpes.

Key takeaway:

Herpes Genitalis is characterized by painful, fluid-filled vesicles that evolve into superficial erosions with polycyclic margins. It is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's symptoms and history of recurrent lesions.

Tag: Herpes genitalis

Reference: Sexually Transmitted Diseases And HIV/AIDS By Vinod K. Sharma, 2nd edition, Pg no 410

questions.text: A patient presented with cough and breathlessness. He was advised a CXR which is shown below. Identify the congenital variation in the Xray given below.
questions.solution:
The azygos lobe is an anatomical variation that occurs in a small percentage of the population (about 1%). Here's a summary of its features and implications

Azygos Lobe Characteristics:

  • Fissure Anatomy: The azygos lobe is formed by an accessory fissure, known as the 'azygos lobe fissure', which is present at the lower end of the azygos vein. This fissure results from incomplete migration of the azygos vein from the chest wall to its normal position near the tracheobronchial angle, and the persistence of invaginated visceral and parietal pleura.
  • Normal Segmental Architecture: Despite the presence of this fissure, there is no corresponding alteration in the segmental architecture of the lung. Hence, the term 'lobe' is technically a misnomer. The lung segments in the azygos lobe region are normal and functionally similar to adjacent segments.
  • Appearance on Imaging: On imaging studies such as chest X-rays or CT scans, the azygos lobe may appear as a smaller, less radiopaque (less transparent to X-rays) area compared to the surrounding normal lung tissue. This difference in appearance is due to its smaller size and the presence of the fissure.

Clinical Considerations:

  • Identification: The azygos lobe can be identified on imaging studies. On a chest X-ray or CT scan, it typically presents as an accessory fissure or lobe with characteristic features. Understanding this variation is important to avoid misdiagnosing it as a pathological condition.

Option A: is not correct as inferior pulmonary ligaments are usually appreciated on CT scan.

Option C: is not correct as the lingular lobe is noted on left side and it is a normal finding and not a variation.

Option D: is also not correct as they run obliquely anteriorly and inferiorly from approximately the fifth thoracic vertebra to pass through the hilum and contact the diaphragm 0-3 cm behind the anterior costophrenic angle.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The azygos lobe is an anatomical variation that occurs in a small percentage of the population (about 1%). Here's a summary of its features and implications

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page no 17.

Tympanostomy tubes are usually required for treatment
Intracranial spread of infection complicates the clinical course.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with a complain of heaviness inside left ear and decreased hearing since 3 months. Endoscopic picture of the affected ear is shown below. Impedance audiometry was done suggestive of type b curve. Which of the following statements is true for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Based on the endoscopic picture and type b curve on impedance audiometry the diagnosis in this case is serous otitis media.
  • It is defined as collection of sterile fluid in the middle ear. So on aspiration of this fluid no organisms are usually isolated hence option d is not true.
  • Also since it's sterile fluid collection the chances of bone erosion and developing an intracranial abscess is negligible thus option c is not true.
  • The collected fluid in the middle ear impairs with the function of impedance matching of the middle ear and usually does not affect the inner ear. Thus it leads to conductive deafness . Hence option A is also not true.
  • It's management primarily includes antihistamines, and decongestant.
  • But if the condition does not resolve even after 3 months then Myringotomy is performed followed by placement of grommet tube or tympanostomy tube to maintain ventilation.

Image reference: Toronto notes website.

Tag 1: Ear, serous otitis media.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL Dhingra, 8th ed, pg 75 76.

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient presented with history of nasal blockage for 6 months. On examination the patient had a nasal mass with mucinous discharge. The CT scan is showing double density sign. What is the most probable diagnosis based on the CT scan given below?
questions.solution:
• The CT scan picture shown above shows haziness of the maxillary sinus and mass in the left nasal cavity without any bony erosion.
  • The CT scan also shows heterogeneous density in the mass known as double density sign. This is characteristic of Allergic fungal rhinitis.
  • Maxillary carcinoma will show bony erosion in CT scan. Antro choanal polyp presents as unilateral nasal mass which is purulent in nature and not mucinous.

Bent and Kuhn criteria of Allergic fungal rhinitis are.

  1. Type 1 hypersensitivity is raised.
  2. Nasal polyps, positive fungal stain.
  3. Biopsy showing fungal elements, allergic mucin.
  4. CT showing hazy sinus with heterogenous appearance.

Tag 1: Nose, Sinusitis and complications.

Reference: Diseases of Ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th ed, pg 184 184.

questions.text: Examine the image of the electron microscope view provided. Which virus is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
• Shape:
    • Typically spherical or oval, with a diameter of about 80-120 nm.
    • Some strains can be pleomorphic, meaning they may vary in shape, occasionally forming filamentous structures.
  • Envelope:
    • The virus is enveloped, meaning it has a lipid membrane derived from the host cell.
    • Embedded in the envelope are two key surface proteins:
      • Hemagglutinin (HA): Responsible for binding to host cell receptors.
      • Neuraminidase (NA): Helps the virus to release from the host cell after replication.
  • Core:
    • Inside the envelope is the viral genome, made up of 8 segments of single-stranded RNA, which are associated with nucleoproteins and packaged in a helical configuration.
  • Surface:
    • The surface of the virus is studded with the HA and NA spikes, which give the virus its characteristic appearance and are crucial for its infectivity.

Explanation:

  • A) HIV: HIV particles are spherical but have a more irregular shape and are covered with a dense layer of glycoprotein spikes, which is different from the spiked structure seen in the image.
  • B) Influenza Virus: Influenza virus particles are spherical with a lipid envelope and characteristic spikes (hemagglutinin and neuraminidase), fitting the description of the image.
  • C) HBV: Hepatitis B virus is more spherical with a less pronounced spiked appearance and has a more complex surface structure.
  • D) HSV: Herpes Simplex Virus is known for its icosahedral capsid structure and does not typically exhibit the spiked envelope seen in the image.

Key Takeaway: The Influenza Virus is characterized by its spherical shape with a spiked envelope. Identifying these spikes helps in distinguishing it from other viruses.

Reference: For more information on the Influenza Virus, refer to the CDC: CDC - Influenza (Flu).

choices.text: Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides): Characterized by its large, cylindrical shape and smooth surface.
Hookworm (Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus): Identified by its hook-like anterior end and the presence of cutting plates or teeth.
Strongyloides (Strongyloides stercoralis): Known for its small size and the presence of rhabditiform larvae with a short buccal cavity.
Whipworm (Trichuris trichiura): Recognizable by its thin, whip-like anterior end and thicker posterior end.

questions.text:
Identify the Parasite from the Image
The image below displays a microscopic view of a parasitic worm. Based on the visible features, which of the following correctly identifies the parasite shown?
questions.solution:
Identified by segmented appearance with blastomeres.

Explanation:

  • A) Incorrect: Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm) is large, cylindrical, and smooth, which does not match the hook-like appearance shown in the image.
  • B) Correct: Ancylostoma duodenale (Hookworm) features a hook-like anterior end and may have cutting plates or teeth. It has segmented eggs with blastomeres.
  • C) Incorrect: Strongyloides stercoralis (Strongyloides) is smaller and characterized by rhabditiform larvae with a short buccal cavity, unlike the hook-like structure.
  • D) Incorrect: Trichuris trichiura (Whipworm) has a thin, whip-like anterior end and thicker posterior end and barrel shaped eggs with mucus plugs.

Key Takeaway: Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus (Hookworms) can be identified by their segmented appearance with blastomeres. This distinguishes them from other parasitic worms based on morphological features.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Hookworm. CDC Hookworm

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman has fingers that are tapered and claw like with decreased motion at the small joints. The microscopic appearance of skin is shown in the figure. The patient also has diffuse interstitial fibrosis of the lungs with pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale. Which of the following dermal inflammatory cell is the most likely the initiator of the process that is the cause of skin disease?
questions.solution:
Clinical history, physical examination and microscopic examination suggestive of scleroderma.

CD4+ lymphocytes are thought to respond to unknown antigens accumulate in the skin and release cytokines that activate inflammatory cells like macrophages, mast cells with fibroblasts.

The result is extensive dermal fibrosis that produces clinical appearance of sclerodactyly in scleroderma.

C & D. Incorrect - Neutrophils and NK cells do not participate in this process.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: CD4+ lymphocytes are thought to respond to unknown antigens accumulate in the skin and release cytokines that activate inflammatory cells like macrophages, mast cells with fibroblasts.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran, 10th edition, page no. 230.

questions.text:
Flow cytometry of a blood from a patient is as below:

What is likely to be the leading cause of disease-related death in this individual?
questions.solution:
1. Shown flow cytometry is from a patient with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).
    • It shows a population of red cell (RED DOTS) that is deficient in both CD55 and CD59.
    • As is typical of PNH, a second population (BLACK DOTS) CD55+, CD59+ that is derived from residual normal hematopoietic stem cells also present.
    • PNH is a rare hematological disorder characterized by the absence of CD55 and CD59 on granulocytes and other blood cells.
    • CD55 and CD59 are complement regulatory proteins that protect cells from complement-mediated lysis.
    • Flow cytometry is used to detect the absence of CD55 and CD59 on granulocytes and other blood cells, which is diagnostic of PNH.
    • PNH patients are at increased risk of venous thrombosis due to the absence of CD55 and CD59, which regulate complement activation.
  2. Arterial thrombosis is less common in PNH.
  3. Hemorrhage is not directly related to PNH.
  4. Infections are not a primary complication of PNH.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran, 10th edition, page no. 649.

questions.text:
A liver biopsy from 35-year-old patient shows

Which of the following mutations is most likely responsible for this?
questions.solution:
• Given image is of Prussian blue stained section, hepatocellular iron appears blue in case of Hereditary hemochromatosis.
  • Hereditary Hemochromatosis (HH) is primarily associated with mutations in the HFE (option A) gene, but other genes can also contribute to the disease.

HFE Gene Mutations:

  • C282Y: Most common mutation, associated with 80-90% of HH cases.
  • H63D: Less penetrant mutation, often found in compound heterozygosity with C282Y.

Other Gene Mutations:

  • TFR2 (Transferrin Receptor 2): Rare mutations associated with juvenile-onset HH
  • SLC40A1 (Ferroportin): Rare mutations associated with ferroportin disease
  • HJV (Hemojuvelin): Rare mutations associated with juvenile-onset HH
  • HAMP (Hepcidin): Rare mutations associated with juvenile-onset HH

Option B. Wilson's Disease: ATP7B gene mutations

Option C. Familial Hypercholesterolemia: LDLR gene mutations

Reference: Robbins & Cotran, 10th edition, page no. 849.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Ewing sarcoma with EWSR1 gene mutation. The technique shown in the image was performed to confirm the diagnosis. Identify the technique shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The technique shown in the image is FISH demonstrates a positive EWSRI gene rearrangement, characteristic of Ewing sarcoma The fused region denoted by Yellow corresponds to a normal intact gene, while a split signal pattern showing separate red and green signals is indicative of EWSRI gene rearrangement.

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is a molecular cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes to bind to specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. The probes are labeled with fluorescent dyes that emit different colors of light. When the probes bind to the DNA, they can be seen under a fluorescent microscope.

The FISH technique is used to detect and localize specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It is used to detect

  • Chromosome abnormalities (Aneuploidy - Down syndrome, Turner syndrome, and Klinefelter syndrome)
  • Microdeletions and rearrangements (Prader-Willi syndrome, Angelman syndrome, and Williams syndrome)
  • Gene Amplification(cancers, including breast cancer and neuroblastoma)
  • Complex Translocations (chronic myeloid leukemia and Burkitt lymphoma)

Option a) Karyotyping is a technique used to study the chromosomes of a cell. The chromosomes are isolated. stained, arranged in pairs, and then photographed. The photographs are then analyzed to look for chromosomal abnormalities. Karyotyping is used to diagnose a variety of genetic disorders, including Down syndrome, Turner syndrome, Klinefelter syndrome, leukemias Lymphomas.

Option c) Immunohistochemistry is a technique used to detect the presence of specific proteins in cells or tissues. The technique uses antibodies that are specific to the protein of interest. The antibodies are labeled with a fluorescent dye or a radioactive isotope. When the antibodies bind to the protein, they can be seen under a microscope. Immunohistochemistry is used to diagnose a variety of diseases, including cancer (ER, PR,HER 2/Neu), autoimmune diseases, and infectious diseases.

Option d) Sanger's technique is a method of DNA sequencing. The technique uses chain termination to determine the order of the nucleotides in a DNA molecule. Sanger's technique is the most commonly used method of DNA sequencing. It is used to identify mutations, diagnose genetic diseases, and study the evolution of genes.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 31st edition, pg no 1075

questions.text: Identify the above logo & select correct option for Composition of food under given program.
questions.solution:
• Mid-Day Meal Scheme was started in India from 15th August 1995 under the name of 'National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education (NP-NSPE)'. In October 2007, NP-NSPE was renamed as 'National Programme of Mid-Day Meal in Schools', which is popularly known as Mid-Day Meal Scheme.
  • In September 2021, the Mid-Day Meal Scheme was renamed 'PM POSHAN' or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman. PM POSHAN will extend the hot cooked meals to students studying in pre-primary levels or Bal Vatikas of government and government-aided primary schools, in addition to those already covered under the mid-day scheme.
  • In formulating mid-day meals for school children, the following broad principles should be kept in mind-
    1. the meal should be a supplement and not a substitute to the home diet;
    2. the meal should supply at least one-third of the total energy requirement, and half of the protein needs.
    3. the cost of the meal should be reasonably low;
    4. the meal should be such that it can be prepared easily in schools; no complicated cooking process should be involved;
    5. as far as possible, locally available foods should be used; this will reduce the cost of the meal; and
    6. the menu should be frequently changed to avoid monotony.

TIPS AND TRICKS

SENSE-C

  • Supplement: The meal should be a supplement and not a substitute to the home diet.
  • Energy & Protein: The meal should supply at least one-third of the total energy requirement and half of the protein need.
  • Not expensive: The cost of the meal should be reasonably low.
  • Simple preparation: The meal should be such that it can be prepared easily in schools; no complicated cooking process should be involved.
  • Eat local: As far as possible, locally available foods should be used; this will reduce the cost of the meal.
  • Change frequently: The menu should be frequently changed to avoid monotony.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Under the Mid Day(Meal Scheme) the meal should supply at least one-third of the total energy requirement, and half of the protein needs

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K. park, 27th Edition, Page no.776

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a rapidly growing blue papule on his neck that has developed over the past 3 months. The lesion is sharply demarcated, measuring 1.5 cm in diameter. He has no previous history of moles in this area. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely variant of malignant melanoma?
questions.solution:
Option A) Incorrect. SSM typically arises in a pre-existing mole and grows slowly over years, before rapid progression in its vertical growth phase.

Option B) Correct. Nodular melanoma tends to present as a rapidly growing, sharply demarcated, blue/black papule, often arising de novo and typically found on the trunk, head, or neck.

Option C) Incorrect. LMM generally presents as a slow-growing, variegated brown macule on sun-exposed areas like the face or hands, often in elderly patients.

Option D) Incorrect. ALM affects the soles and palms, more commonly in darker-skinned individuals, and presents as a flat macule, often amelanotic.

Key Points:

  • Hutchinson's Sign: Pigmentation of the nail fold in subungual melanoma.
  • Desmoplastic Melanoma: Found on the head/neck with a propensity for perineural infiltration; often amelanotic.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 45, Pages-656

choices.text: Epigastric hernias commonly contain bowel and pose a high risk of strangulation.
The most common cause of recurrence is failure to identify multiple hernia defects during initial surgery.
These hernias arise through the lateral rectus sheath and not the linea alba.
Epigastric hernias are always reducible and rarely cause pain.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old healthy male presents with a small, painful swelling in the midline between his umbilicus and xiphoid process. The swelling is firm, non-reducible, and has been increasing in size over the past few months. He feels the pain worsens with coughing or straining, though he reports no significant bowel issues. On examination, a small, tender mass is felt over the linea alba, with no clear cough impulse.

Which of the following statements about epigastric hernias is true?
questions.solution:
Epigastric Hernia

  • Anatomy: These hernias occur through the midline raphe (linea alba) between the xiphoid process and umbilicus, often due to a transverse split in the linea alba.
  • Common Contents: Frequently contain extraperitoneal fat, rarely containing bowel.
  • Clinical Features: Small, firm, and often painful; may resemble a lipoma. Cough impulse may or may not be present, and the hernia is typically non-reducible.
  • Complications: Painful due to fat strangulation, rarely life-threatening unless bowel is involved.
  • Treatment: Small hernias can spontaneously resolve. Symptomatic hernias or those with bowel content require surgery, either open or laparoscopic.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. Epigastric hernias rarely contain bowel and are more likely to contain extraperitoneal fat, which causes the pain.

Option B) Correct. Recurrence is often due to failure to identify multiple defects during surgery, as there may be more than one hernia.

Option C) Incorrect. These hernias arise through the midline raphe (linea alba) and not the lateral rectus sheath.

Option D) Incorrect. Epigastric hernias are often non-reducible and frequently cause pain due to fat entrapment.

Key Points:

Recurrence: Most common cause is failure to identify multiple defects.

Tags:

  • Topic: Epigastric Hernia
  • Difficulty Level: Must Know

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the neurology clinic by his parents due to frequent daily seizures, including tonic seizures during sleep and atonic (drop) attacks while awake. His developmental milestones have been delayed, and he is attending a special education program due to intellectual disability. The parents report that the seizures have been difficult to control despite multiple anti-epileptic medications. An EEG shows following discharges at a frequency of 2-2.5 Hz, along with bursts of fast rhythms during sleep. Based on this presentation, you suspect the boy has a severe childhood epilepsy syndrome.

Which epilepsy syndrome is most commonly associated with this presentation in childhood?
questions.solution:
• Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a severe childhood epilepsy syndrome that typically begins between the ages of 3 and 8 years. It is characterized by multiple seizure types (tonic, atonic, and absence seizures are common), intellectual disability, and intractable epilepsy (seizures that are difficult to control with medications).
  • EEG findings in LGS include slow spike-and-wave discharges during wakefulness and fast rhythms during sleep, which are hallmark features.
  • Children with LGS often exhibit developmental delays and intellectual disability as part of the syndrome. Seizures are often refractory to treatment, and the prognosis is typically poor due to ongoing cognitive and behavioral issues.
  • Option A (Childhood absence epilepsy): Typically presents with absence seizures in school-aged children without intellectual disability, and the seizures are often well controlled with medication.
  • Option C (Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy): Characterized by myoclonic jerks, typically occurring in adolescence, with normal intellectual function. Seizures are generally responsive to treatment.
  • Option D (Temporal lobe epilepsy): Often presents with focal seizures in older children or adults, and intellectual disability is not a common feature.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a severe childhood epilepsy syndrome associated with intellectual disability and multiple types of refractory seizures.
  • It is often diagnosed by the presence of slow spike-and-wave EEG discharges and multiple seizure types, including tonic and atonic seizures.
  • Management of LGS is challenging due to intractable epilepsy and the poor cognitive prognosis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 425, Pages 3305-3323.

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents with severe chest pain and vomiting after ingesting a caustic substance. Endoscopy reveals multiple areas of sloughing mucosa with deep ulcerations extending into the submucosa and muscularis propria. According to Zargar's classification, what grade of esophageal injury does this represent?
questions.solution:
Caustic Esophageal Injuries

  • Aetiology: Common in children (accidental) and adults (suicidal intent).
  • Injury severity depends on type, pH, quantity, and exposure duration of ingested substance (acid or alkali).
    • Acid: Causes coagulative necrosis with eschar formation, limiting deeper penetration.
    • Alkali: Leads to liquefactive necrosis, penetrating deeper and causing more severe injury.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms: Neck, throat, chest, or abdominal pain; drooling, dysphagia, odynophagia, hoarseness (laryngeal injury).
    • Emergency signs: Hoarseness indicates potential airway obstruction, requiring urgent intubation or surgical airway.
  • Initial assessments include airway management, intravenous fluids, oxygen, and cardiorespiratory monitoring.
  • Imaging/Endoscopy: CT scan with contrast and endoscopy to evaluate injury extent (Zargar grading).
  • Management:
    • Supportive treatment: Initial care includes securing airway, fluid resuscitation, and oxygen supplementation.
    • Surgical intervention: Emergency esophagectomy may be required for deteriorating cases. Delayed reconstruction planned later.
    • Nutritional support: Nasogastric or feeding jejunostomy may be used, especially if strictures form.
  • Complications:
    • Stricture formation: More likely in severe, circumferential injuries. Dilatation has a higher perforation risk.
    • Malignancy risk: Strictures can become resistant to treatment; esophagectomy or bypass surgery may be necessary. Bypass with gastric conduit (retrosternal route) or colonic interposition if the stomach is also damaged.

Explanation of Options:

  1. Grade I: Incorrect. Grade I injuries are characterized by edema and erythema of the mucosa without ulceration or sloughing.
  2. Grade IIa: Incorrect. Grade IIa injuries involve superficial ulcerations and noncircumferential sloughing of mucosa.
  3. Grade IIb: Incorrect. Grade IIb injuries involve deep ulcerations but limited to the mucosa and submucosa, not extending into the muscularis propria.
  4. Grade III: Correct. Grade III injuries involve extensive ulcerations and necrosis extending into the submucosa and muscularis propria, indicating severe esophageal damage.

Key Points:

  • Avoid gastric lavage or neutralization. Emergency airway management is crucial.
  • Most injuries managed conservatively, with surgery reserved for deteriorating cases.Long-term risks include stricture formation and malignancy

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 66, page no. 1130

questions.text: 58-year-old woman has experienced an increasing feeling of fullness in the neck for the past 3 months, and she has noted a 3-kg weight loss during that time. On physical examination, there is a firm, fixed mass in a 3 x 5 cm area in the right side of the neck. CT scan shows a solid mass in the region of the right lobe of the thyroid gland. A biopsy of the mass is performed; the microscopic appearance of the specimen is shown in the figure. All areas of the tumor have similar morphology. Which of the following terms best describes this neoplasm?
questions.solution:
B. The cells shown in the figure show marked pleomorphism and hyperchromatism (anaplasia). A bizarre tripolar mitotic figure is present.

This degree of anaplasia is consistent with a malignancy.

Anaplasia is a term used in pathology to describe the loss of cellular differentiation and a characteristic of malignant tumors. It refers to a reversion of cells to a more primitive or undifferentiated state.

The key features of anaplasia include:

  1. Pleomorphism: Cells and nuclei exhibit marked variation in size and shape, with no uniformity in cell structure.
  2. Hyperchromatism: The nuclei of anaplastic cells are darker than normal due to an increased amount of DNA, indicating abnormal chromatin content.
  3. Increased Nuclear-Cytoplasmic Ratio: Nuclei are disproportionately large compared to the cytoplasm, giving cells an abnormal appearance.
  4. Abnormal Mitotic Figures: Increased and atypical mitoses are present, indicating rapid and uncontrolled cell division.
  5. Loss of Tissue Architecture: Cells lose their normal orientation and arrangement, resulting in a lack of organized tissue structure.

Incorrect Options:

A. An adenoma is a benign Tumor of glandular origin.

C & D. Adenocarcinomas and squamous cell carcinomas show differentiation into glandular or squamous tissues.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Anaplasia is a term used in pathology to describe the loss of cellular differentiation and a characteristic of malignant tumors. It refers to a reversion of cells to a more primitive or undifferentiated state.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran, 10th edition, page no. 271.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is likely to produce the effect on action potential as shown in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
• The figure shows that the drug decreases slope of phase 0 (Na+ channel blockade) and also it decreases action potential duration (K+ channel opener).
  • These are the actions of anti-arrhythmic drugs belonging to class Ib like Lignocaine.

Class IB Agents

  • Class Ib antiarrhythmic agents (lignocaine, mexiletine, tocainide and phenytoin) are sodium channel blockers (block Na channels in inactivated state) that possess K+ channel opening property.
  • Class Ib agents have fast onset and offset kinetics (τ < 1s), meaning that they have little or no effect at slower heart rates, and more effects at faster heart rates.
  • These agents shorten the APD and reduce refractoriness (because of the opening of K+ channels).
  • These agents will decrease Vmax in partially depolarized cells with fast response action potential.
  • They do not change the APD in non-depolarized tissues.
  • These drugs are used only for ventricular arrhythmia.
  • It is the drug of choice for the treatment of ventricular arrhythmias due to digitalis toxicity (ineffective in atrial arrhythmias).
  • It is also the first-line drug for ventricular arrhythmias after myocardial infarction.

Key takeaway:

  • Class Ib antiarrhythmic agents (lignocaine, mexiletine, tocainide and phenytoin) are sodium channel blockers (block Na channels in inactivated state) that possess K+ channel opening property, hence decreases slope of phase 0 (Na+ channel blockade) and also it decreases action potential duration (K+ channel opener).

Tags:

  • Good to Know
  • Lignocaine

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 575

questions.text: The corneal findings present in the below image are commonly observed with which of the following drugs indicated in glaucoma?
questions.solution:
• A bilateral whorl-like corneal pattern of cream colored lines, as shown in the above image, is called corneal verticillata.
  • Corneal verticillata is observed with the use of netarsudil. The incidence is more than 20%. It is usually mild and irreversible and not associated with any significant visual abnormalities.

Corneal verticillata causes:

  • Fabry's disease
  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Indomethacin
  • Phenothiazines

Summary of Adverse Effects of Anti-Glaucoma medications

Key takeaway:

questions.text: Above image shows Enzyme Inhibition by malonate (Enzyme - Succinate Dehydrogenase). Identify the type of Enzyme Inhibition.
questions.solution:
The relationship between reaction velocity (v) Vmax and the Michaelis Constant (Km) is described by Michaelis - Menten Equation. It is useful for understanding enzymatic reactions. As shown in image Vmax remain same but Km is changed suggestive of Competitive Inhibition.

Option A) In Competitive Inhibitor, Inhibitor binds with substrate binding site by blocking the access by the substrate

Option B) In noncompetitive Inhibitor, Inhibitor binds enzyme at distant site than substrate binding site. In noncompetitive inhibition, Vmax is decreased but Km remain constant. Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition. E.g Pyruvate Kinase inhibited by Alanine.

OptionC) Uncompetitive inhibitors do not compete with the substrate for binding to the active site, and they only bind to the enzyme-substrate complex.

Option D) Suicidal Inhibition involving Enzyme undergoes self destruction in order to terminate its own activity. E.g Allopurinol inhibits Xanthine Oxidase

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated review SAE, Chapter 10, Page 142-143

Cross Linking of Collagen fibers is adequately present

questions.text: Above image shows characteristic sign of Ecchymoses due to deficiency of Micronutrient. What is the pathogenesis behind above presentation.
questions.solution:
• The Deficiency of vitamin C results in scurvy. The clinical Features are Swollen Joints, Fatigue, Irritability, Bleeding into the skin, Perifollicular Hemorrhage, pseudo paralysis.
  • Majority of the Deficiency symptoms are due to deficient collagen synthesis. In deficiency of vitamin C, Post translational modification of collagen fibers, hydroxylate of Prolyl and lysyl residues of collagen did not occur.

Defective Cross linking of collagen fibers is seen. It requires presence of Ferrous Ion and Molecular Oxygen.

Patient with scurvy often show ecchymoses (Bruise like discoloration) on the limbs as a result of subcutaneous extravasation of blood due to capillary fragility and not due to fluid.

Other features of Scurvy include Osteopenia, Cortical Thinning, Subperiosteal Hemorrhage, Scorbutic Rosary, Pelken Spur may be seen on radiological examination.

questions.text: A 30 years old Male presented with above cutaneous manifestation on sun exposed areas along with increase in urine uroporphyrin levels, what should be your probable Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Cutaneous manifestation seen in above image over the sun exposed area is skin eruption due to accumulation of porphyrin mainly seen in most common type of Porphyria - Chronic Hepatic Porphyria - also known as Porphyria Cutanea Tarda.
  • The disease is associated with Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. It is mainly Autosomal Dominant Disorder. Clinical Manifestation depends on hepatic iron overload, exposure to sunlight, alcohol ingestion, oestrogen therapy and seen in fourth/fifth decades of life.
  • Conversion of Uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III is deficient leading to increase in Uroporphyrin levels also appears in urine.

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated Review, Chapter 26, Page 419-420

questions.text: Match the following liver status scores with their respective uses and components.
questions.solution:
1. Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) Score (1-D):
    • Use: Assesses liver function and prognosis in cirrhosis.
    • Components: Bilirubin, albumin, INR, ascites, and encephalopathy.
  2. Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) Score (2-B):
    • Use: Predicts mortality and prioritizes liver transplant candidates.
    • Components: Bilirubin, INR, creatinine, and sodium (recently added in MELD-Na).
  3. Lille Score (3-C):
    • Use: Evaluates response to corticosteroids in severe alcoholic hepatitis.
    • Components: Includes bilirubin levels before and after 7 days of corticosteroid therapy.
  4. Maddrey's Discriminant Function (DF) (4-A):
    • Use: Assesses prognosis in alcoholic hepatitis.
    • Components: Bilirubin and prothrombin time (PT). A DF >32 indicates severe disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • The CTP score is widely used for grading cirrhosis and assessing the need for TIPS or transplant.
  • The MELD score prioritizes liver transplantation.
  • The Lille score is critical in adjusting corticosteroid therapy in alcoholic hepatitis.
  • Maddrey’s DF identifies severe alcoholic hepatitis requiring steroids.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, pg 2617-22, 35,36,37.

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient brought to ophthalmologist with the feature seen in the following image. He had a history having taking one of the following atypical antipsychotic agents. Which of the following drug is responsible for following side effect?
questions.solution:
• The image shows the formation of cataract in one of the eyes.
  • Atypical antipsychotic quetiapine is associated with cataract formation
  • The manufacturer recommends eye examinations to detect cataracts at baseline and at 6-month intervals in patients treated with quetiapine.
  • Since the advent of Second generations of antipsychotics (SGAs), there has been increased concern over metabolic effects of treatment: weight gain, dyslipidemia (particularly hypertriglyceridemia), and an adverse impact on glucose-insulin homeostasis
  • Clozapine, olanzapine, and higher dose quetiapine have the highest metabolic risk and are not considered first-line agents.
  • The ability of antipsychotics to induce hyperglycemia was first noted during low-potency phenothiazine treatment; indeed, chlorpromazine was occasionally exploited for this specific property as adjunctive presurgical treatment of insulinoma.
  • As SGAs gained widespread use, numerous papers documented the association of new-onset diabetes and diabetic ketoacidosis with SGA exposure, especially during clozapine, olanzapine, and quetiapine therapy.

Key takeaway:

  • Quetiapine can cause cataract formation

Tags:

  • May Know
  • Quetiapine

Reference: Goodman & Gillman's the pharmacological basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 362

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and atrial fibrillation presents with progressive cognitive decline over the past year. His wife reports that his condition has worsened in a stepwise manner, with periods of stability followed by sudden deteriorations. He also complains of gait instability and has experienced episodes of urinary incontinence. On physical examination, he has spasticity and hyperreflexia in both lower limbs. MRI of the brain reveals
What is the most likely underlying cause of his dementia?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of vascular risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, and atrial fibrillation), along with his stepwise cognitive decline and

MRI findings of lacunar infarcts and white matter changes, points towards Vascular Dementia.

This condition is driven by chronic ischemia and small vessel disease, which progressively damage brain tissue over time.

  • Option A refers to Alzheimer's Disease, which typically presents with gradual cognitive decline and is associated with beta-amyloid plaques, primarily affecting memory.
  • Option B describes Frontotemporal Dementia, characterized by personality changes and behavioural issues, not a stepwise cognitive decline.
  • Option D points towards Dementia with Lewy Bodies, which is characterized by visual hallucinations, cognitive fluctuations, and parkinsonism, rather than vascular risk factors or stepwise progression.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Vascular Dementia often presents with stepwise cognitive decline, corresponding to cerebrovascular events such as lacunar infarcts.
  2. It is crucial to differentiate between vascular pathology and neurodegenerative conditions like Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia with Lewy Bodies, which have distinct clinical and imaging findings.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no: 3370-85

choices.text: It is a highly specific scan that detects parathyroid glands but cannot detect ectopic glands
This scan has sensitivity and specificity is lower than ultrasound for parathyroid adenomas
Parathyroid adenomas retain longer than the thyroid gland due to high mitochondrial content
These scans are primarily useful in detecting medullary thyroid cancer

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with persistent hypercalcemia and is diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. The surgeon plans for parathyroidectomy and orders a scan for preoperative localization. What is the most accurate statement regarding this scanning?
questions.solution:
Sestamibi Scanning for Parathyroid Localization

  • Purpose: Used to localize parathyroid adenomas in patients with primary hyperparathyroidism. It is considered the most reliable imaging technique for preoperative parathyroid gland localization.
  • Mechanism: Sestamibi accumulates in mitochondria, and parathyroid adenomas with high oxyphilic content retain the tracer longer than thyroid tissue.
  • Protocols: Three protocols are used:
    • Single-isotope dual-phase scan
    • Dual-isotope subtraction imaging
    • Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT)
  • Sensitivity and Specificity: Approximately 79% sensitivity and 90% specificity, making it highly effective in detecting adenomas.
  • False Positives: Rare but can occur with Hürthle cell thyroid nodules, which also retain sestamibi due to their high oxyphilic content. These false positives can be reduced using thyroid-specific tracers such as 99Tc-pertechnetate and subtraction imaging.

Option A) Incorrect. Sestamibi scans are highly effective in detecting parathyroid glands and are particularly helpful in identifying ectopic glands.

Option B) Incorrect. The sensitivity and specificity of sestamibi scans are similar to ultrasonography, but sestamibi may be better at detecting ectopic glands.

Option C) Correct. Parathyroid adenomas often have a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with abundant mitochondria, resulting in longer retention of sestamibi compared to thyroid tissue.

Option D) Incorrect. Sestamibi scans are not used primarily for detecting medullary thyroid cancer; they are primarily used for parathyroid adenoma localization.

Key Points:

Sestamibi scanning is the most reliable method for imaging parathyroid adenomas, especially for ectopic glands. Adenomas retain sestamibi longer due to their high mitochondrial content.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 56, Page no: 877

choices.text: Most common cause of stridor in new-born

questions.text:
A 6 month old baby presented with complain of stridor. The stridor was inspiratory in nature and get aggravated on crying and sleeping in supine position, and it gets relieved on making child prone. Laryngoscopic examination was done and picture is given below. Which of the following is not true about this condition?
Tag 1: larynx congenital deformities
questions.solution:
• Based on the clinical features and picture the diagnosis is laryngomalacia.
  • It is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx and also the most common cause of stridor in infants.
  • Main presentation is of stridor which is inspiratory in nature and peaks around 6 months of age . The stridor worsens on crying and in supine position and improves in prone position.
  • Laryngoscopy examination reveals curled up Epiglottis or omega shaped Epiglottis. The arytenoids and the AE folds appears flabby
  • Management: As the larynx grows all the redundant tissue is taken up and the stridor disappears by 2 years of age. So management is by conservative by reassurance.
  • Rarely excision of excessive redundant tissue is done called supraglottoplasty.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi, page no: 344.

Image reference: Respiratory medicine today website.

questions.text: The device shown in the picture below is used in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
The device shown in the picture given above is called Grommet. Grommet is a ventilation tube or tympanostomy tube for ventilating and draining the middle ear, the same function as that of eustachian tube.

The Grommet is used in the management of serous otitis media SOM. Myringotomy with grommet insertion along with treatment of causative factor I.e. adenoidectomy or tonsillectomy etc. Hence option C is correct.

The main management of ASOM is medical management including antibiotics and anti inflammatory. Hence Option A is not correct.

The main management of safe CSOM is Tympanoplasty with or without ossicular reconstruction. Hence option B is not correct.

The main management of Unsafe CSOM is Mastoidectomy either canal wall up or canal wall down depending upon extent of disease thus option D is also not correct.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi, page no: 70.

choices.text: Observe and wait for the coin to pass
Administer muscle relaxants and repeat Xray
Perform a barium swallow to confirm location

questions.text: A 3 year old child is brought to the emergency department with a history of swallowing a coin. He is drooling, has difficulty swallowing, and is gagging. An Xray confirms a foreign body lodged at the level of the cricopharyngeal muscle. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Management of Foreign Body in Esophagus

  1. Common Sites of Lodgement:
  • Cricopharyngeus muscle (upper esophagus).
  • Aortic arch and left main bronchus (middle esophagus).
  • Lower esophageal sphincter (distal esophagus).
  1. Clinical Presentation:
  • Drooling, gagging, dysphagia, chest pain, or refusal to eat.
  • Airway compromise if large or sharp objects are involved.
  1. Diagnosis:
  • Xray for radiopaque objects.
  • CT scan or endoscopy if not visible on Xray or if complications are suspected.
  1. Management:
  • Flexible Endoscopy: Main method for foreign body extraction using forceps, nets, baskets, or balloons. Airway protection may be required.
  • Special Considerations: Sharp objects should be retrieved carefully to avoid perforation. Batteries must be removed immediately due to the risk of electrical burn or liquefactive necrosis.
  • Food Bolus: Can be broken down or pushed into the stomach.
  1. Observe and wait for the coin to pass: Incorrect. Observation is not advised if a foreign body is lodged at the cricopharyngeus, especially in symptomatic children.
  2. Endoscopic removal under general anaesthesia: Correct. Immediate endoscopic removal is necessary due to the risk of airway obstruction and aspiration.
  3. Administer muscle relaxants and repeat Xray: Incorrect. This approach does not address the immediate need for foreign body removal.
  4. Perform a barium swallow to confirm location: Incorrect. Barium swallow is not indicated in known foreign body ingestion confirmed by Xray.

Key Points:

  • Immediate endoscopic removal is essential for symptomatic foreign bodies lodged in the oesophagus.
  • Delay in treatment increases the risk of complications like perforation and aspiration.

Reference: ENT textbook by DHINGRA 7th edition, page no: 397.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy presents with a non retractable foreskin. Examination shows a tight, fibrous ring at the preputial opening, making retraction difficult. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Phimosis

Phimosis is a condition where the foreskin cannot be retracted over the glans penis due to a tight, fibrous ring.

Types

  • Physiological phimosis: Normal in infants and young children.
  • Pathological phimosis: Caused by scarring or infection.

Symptoms

  • Difficulty retracting foreskin
  • Ballooning of foreskin during urination
  • Recurrent infections (balanitis)

Management

  • Observation: Physiological phimosis often resolves on its own.
  • Topical corticosteroids: Can help to reduce inflammation and improve foreskin retractability.
  • Circumcision: May be necessary for pathological phimosis or recurrent infections.

Option A: Paraphimosis isIncorrect. Paraphimosis occurs when the foreskin is retracted and cannot be returned over the glans, leading to swelling and pain.

Option B: Balanoposthitis is Incorrect. Balanoposthitis refers to inflammation of the glans and foreskin, typically due to infection or poor hygiene.

Option C: Phimosis is Correct. Phimosis is the inability to retract the foreskin over the glans penis due to a tight preputial ring, commonly seen in young boys.

Option D: Penile cancer is Incorrect. Penile cancer presents as a growth or ulcerative lesion, often with other symptoms like bleeding or discharge.

Key Takeaway:

  • Phimosis is common in young boys and usually resolves naturally; persistent cases may require medical or surgical treatment.
  • Observation is appropriate for physiological phimosis; circumcision may be needed for pathological phimosis.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 85, Pages 1548
