choices.text: Wide excision of the nipple and areola, including underlying ducts, followed by radiotherapy
Mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection
No further action if there is no associated malignancy

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with eczematous changes to the nipple that have not responded to topical steroids. There is associated destruction of the nipple and encroachment onto the areola. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Paget's Disease of the Nipple

  • A rare type of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) presenting in the nipple and areola.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Erosion of the nipple with slow destruction, usually without an underlying mass. Often mistaken for eczema.
  • Pathophysiology: Paget's cells migrate through the ducts into the skin of the nipple.
  • Diagnosis: Wedge biopsy confirms the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Without underlying malignancy: Central core excision(removal of major milk ducts, nipple, and areola) followed by radiotherapy.
    • with underlying malignancy: Mastectomy and axillary node evaluation.

Option A) Incorrect. Persistent eczematous changes that do not respond to steroids.

Option B) Incorrect. Wide excision alone may be insufficient.

Option C) Correct. Paget's disease of the breast is often associated with an underlying ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or invasive carcinoma. The standard treatment is mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection, especially when there is evidence of an underlying malignancy.

Option D) Incorrect. as it is often associated with breast cancer

Key Points:

Associated with DCIS but may progress to invasive carcinoma.

Triple assessment (clinical exam, imaging, biopsy) is mandatory to exclude underlying malignancy.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 58, Pages no: 924.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old gardener presents with a chronic, ulcerated lesion on the hand. The patient reports that the lesion initially appeared as a small bump and has progressively developed into an ulcer with multiple satellite lesions. A biopsy was performed, and the microscopic image shows small, cigar-shaped yeast cells with branching hyphae.
Based on the microscopic image, which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with the observed findings?
questions.solution:
• Sporothrix schenckii causes Rose Gardener's disease/sporotrichosis.
  • The lesion begins as a small nodule at the site of thorn prick and progressively develops into multiple, satellite nodules along the lymphatic drainage pathway.
  • Histopathological examination - in the centre there is a round-shaped cigar body -yeast and surrounding it there are projections -Splendore hoeppli (Ag-Ab reaction) and together it is called asteroid body .

Lymphocutaneous spread

Cigar shaped yeast and asteroid bodies

Rosettes of microconidia

  • A) Sporotrichosis: The image shows cigar-shaped yeast cells with branching hyphae, characteristic of Sporothrix schenckii. This fungus causes sporotrichosis, often presenting as a chronic ulcerative skin lesion with a history of plant thorn injury.
  • B) Candidiasis: Typically shows budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae, rather than cigar-shaped yeast cells. Candidiasis is usually found in mucosal or systemic infections, not typically presenting with the described skin lesion.
  • C) Blastomycosis: This fungus causes broad-based budding yeast cells, which are different from the cigar-shaped cells seen in sporotrichosis. Blastomycosis often presents with more systemic symptoms and chronic skin lesions.
  • D) Histoplasmosis: This fungal infection is usually characterized by small intracellular yeast cells within macrophages and does not show cigar-shaped yeast cells. Histoplasmosis commonly presents with respiratory symptoms and disseminated disease.

Key Takeaway: Sporotrichosis is diagnosed by identifying cigar-shaped yeast cells with branching hyphae in tissue samples, reflecting the infection by Sporothrix schenckii.

Reference:

  • CDC Sporotrichosis Overview
  • Dermatology textbooks or infectious disease references for details on the microscopic features of fungal infections.

questions.text: Identify the following property of nerve muscle diagram.
questions.solution:
• Option A: In the diagram at one voltage potential, the channel may remain closed all the time or almost all the time, whereas at another voltage, it may remain open either all or most of the time. The diagram depicts all or none law.
  • Option B: Refractory period refers to the time period following an action potential during which a neuron or muscle fiber is less responsive or unresponsive to additional stimuli. It is different in different excitable tissues.
  • Option C - Impulse conduction depends on

Myelination - saltatory conduction

Unmyelinated - continuous conduction

  • Option D: In the graded potential as the strength of stimulus increases the response increases. It does not fit with the diagram. It is not the correct option.

Reference: Guyton and Hall textbook of Medical physiology 14th ed, ch 4, fig 4-6, page no: 55, 74, 76

questions.text: HIV positive person with CD 4 count of <50/cu mm of blood. Presented with lesion shown in image. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
CMV Retinitis (Cytomegalovirus Retinitis) is an opportunistic eye infection primarily seen in immunocompromised patients, especially those with advanced HIV/AIDS or organ transplants.

  1. Causative Agent: Cytomegalovirus (CMV), a herpesvirus, is the causative agent of this retinal infection.
  2. Risk Factors:
    • Immunosuppression, particularly in patients with CD4 counts below 50 cells/μL in HIV/AIDS.
    • Organ transplant recipients on immunosuppressive therapy.
    • Long-term corticosteroid or chemotherapy use.
  3. Symptoms:
    • Blurred vision or decreased visual acuity.
    • Floaters or flashes of light.
    • Loss of peripheral vision (can progress to blindness if untreated).
    • Often asymptomatic in early stages.
  4. Fundoscopic Findings:
    • "Pizza pie" or "cheese and ketchup" appearance due to hemorrhagic retinal necrosis.
    • White, granular retinal infiltrates with haemorrhages.
    • Retinal atrophy in chronic cases.

Here is a tabular representation of opportunistic infections associated with a CD4 count of <50 cells/mm³ in an HIV-positive person:

KEY TAKEAWAYS: CMV Retinitis (Cytomegalovirus Retinitis) is an opportunistic eye infection primarily seen in immunocompromised patients, especially those with advanced HIV/AIDS or organ transplants.

Reference: National Guideline for HIV Care & Treatment, MOHFW, GOI, section no: 3, Page No: 78-83. https://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National_Guidelines_for_HIV_Care_and_Treatment_2021.pdf

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with new-onset seizures and is found to have multiple brain metastases on MRI. Which is the most likely primary site of his metastases?
questions.solution:
Option A) Breast: Can metastasize to the brain, but less common in men compared to lung cancer.

Option B) Renal: Renal cell carcinoma can spread to the brain, but it is less frequent than lung cancer.

Option C) Lung: Correct. Lung cancer is the most common cause of brain metastases.

Option D) Melanoma: Melanoma often metastasizes to the brain, but lung cancer remains the most common primary source.

Key Points:

Lung cancer is the most common primary tumour causing brain metastases. Brain metastases often indicate advanced disease and require multimodal treatment.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Page no: 714.

choices.text: Suction evacuation is done for the management of the condition
The ovaries might show large cysts in this patient
Her beta HCG levels are lower than expected for the gestational age.
This patient may present with tachycardia, sweating and cold intolerance

questions.text: 23 year old primigravida 12 weeks 2 days pregnancy, presents to the labour room with complain of bleeding per vaginum. On the USG the following is visualised. What is incorrect about the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The USG shows a picture of snowstorm appearance suggestive of complete molar pregnancy.
  • Complete molar pregnancy has no identifiable fetal tissue.
  • The chorionic villi have edematous swelling and diffuse chorionic hyperplasia(Option B).
  • Patient presents with vaginal bleeding in pregnancy. Uterus is larger than period of gestation.
  • The HCG levels are more than the period of gestation. It may be associated with theca lutein cyst in ovaries, hyperemesis and early onset pre eclampsia.
  • Due to high HCG levels, features of hyperthyroidism like tachycardia, sweating and cold intolerance also seen.(Option D)
  • If fertility is not desired then hysterectomy is done. If fertility is desired then suction evacuation is the management of choice.(Option A)
  • Anti D is given if the mother is Rh negative and father is Rh positive.

Reference: D.C. dutta textbook of obstetrics, 9/e, chapter 16, page no: 180.

questions.text: Identify the image given below?
questions.solution:
T1-weighted imaging (T1WI) is a fundamental type of MRI sequence that provides information about tissue properties.

  1. Appearance:
  • Fat: Appears bright (high signal intensity) because fat has a short T1 relaxation time.
  • Water and fluid (e.g., cerebrospinal fluid, cysts): Appears dark (low signal intensity) due to a longer T1 relaxation time.
  • Muscle, soft tissue, and gray matter: Intermediate signal intensity.
  • White matter: Slightly brighter than gray matter due to its fat content.
  1. Purpose:
  • Used for anatomical detail and structural imaging because it provides high contrast between different tissues.
  • Particularly useful for visualizing fat-containing tissues, detecting hemorrhage, and assessing the integrity of brain structures.
  1. Clinical Applications:
  • Brain MRI: Good for detecting anatomical abnormalities, brain structure, and some tumors (especially those with fat content).
  • Spine MRI: Helpful for assessing spinal anatomy and detecting changes in spinal cord structure.
  • Musculoskeletal MRI: Used to differentiate fat from other tissues and evaluate bone marrow, muscles, and tendons.
  1. Contrast Enhancement:
  • When gadolinium-based contrast agents are used, T1-weighted imaging is excellent for detecting areas of enhancement, which often correspond to regions of increased blood flow, inflammation, or breakdown of the blood-brain barrier (e.g., tumors, infections, active demyelinating lesions).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: T1-weighted MRI is a fundamental imaging technique, often used in conjunction with other MRI sequences, like T2-weighted or FLAIR, to give a comprehensive view of both normal anatomy and pathological changes.

Reference: MRI made easy, second edition, page no: 14

choices.text: Discard vial, use another new vial
Use vaccine but give double dose
Keep in freezer. Will use tomorrow

questions.text: For giving opv vaccine, worker taken out opv vial from ice lined refrigerator. Suddenly he noticed that colour of inner square of vaccine vial monitor is dark purple. He asked from his senior doctor about this. What could be advise of senior doctor?
questions.solution:
• The color change in the vaccine vial monitor (VVM), which indicates that the inner square has turned dark purple, suggests that the vaccine has been exposed to inappropriate temperatures (either too high or too low) and may no longer be effective.
  • OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) is sensitive to temperature changes, and its efficacy can be compromised if it has been stored outside the recommended temperature range. The VVM helps to ensure the vaccine is still potent.
  • Do not worry, give vaccine is not appropriate because using a vaccine with a changed VVM color could result in ineffective vaccination.
  • Use vaccine but give double dose is also not recommended as it does not address the issue of potential ineffectiveness due to improper storage.
  • Keep in freezer and use tomorrow is not a solution because the vaccine should not be stored in a freezer, and the color change indicates that the vaccine might already be compromised.

Thus, the safest course of action is to discard the vial and use a new, properly stored vial to ensure the vaccine's efficacy and safety.

Summary of the stages of a Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM):

Reference: Immunization_Handbook_for_Medical_Officers 2017,MOHFW,GOI, unit no.-04, Page No: 19-26.

questions.text: A gastroscopic image of a patient with hematemesis is shown below. Which of the following drug is indicated?
questions.solution:
• The above picture depicts a gastroscopy image of esophageal varices with prominent cherry-red spots.
  • Octreotide is indicated in the treatment of acute variceal bleeding.
  • Octreotide is a somatostatin analog that reduces azygous blood flow significantly and decreases variceal bleeding.

Octreotide

  • This synthetic octapeptide surrogate of somatostatin is 40 times more potent in suppressing GH secretion and longer acting.
  • It is preferred over somatostatin for acromegaly and secretory diarrhoeas associated with carcinoid, AIDS, cancer chemotherapy or diabetes.
  • Control of diarrhoea is due to suppression of hormones which enhance intestinal mucosal secretion.
  • Octreotide injected i.v. reduces hepatic blood flow and helps stop esophageal variceal bleeding.

Key Takeaway:

  • Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue having high potency and long duration of action. It is preferred over somatostatin for all the indications like acromegaly and secretory diarrhoeas associated with carcinoid, AIDS, cancer chemotherapy or diabetes.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no: 260

questions.text: Match the clinical condition with the characteristic pathogens commonly associated with it:
questions.solution:
• 1 - A: Overwhelming post-splenectomy sepsis is commonly caused by encapsulated organisms like Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae.
  • 2 - B: Toxic shock syndrome is primarily associated with Staphylococcus aureus and Group A Streptococcus, which produce exotoxins.
  • 3 - C: Meningococcemia is caused by Neisseria meningitidis, a leading cause of bacterial sepsis and meningitis.
  • 4 - D: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, transmitted by ticks.

Key Takeaways:

  • Prompt and targeted therapy based on the suspected pathogen can significantly reduce morbidity and mortality in infectious conditions.
  • Early recognition and management of toxin-mediated infections like toxic shock syndrome are critical for patient outcomes.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 122, page no: 948-59.

questions.text: Match the following liver disorders with their characteristic laboratory findings:
questions.solution:
1. Hemolysis/Gilbert's Syndrome (1-D):
    • Normal ALP, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, and normal liver enzymes indicate Gilbert's syndrome or hemolysis.
  2. Acute Hepatocellular Necrosis (2-A):
    • Marked elevation in ALT and AST (>500 IU) with both bilirubin fractions elevated is consistent with acute hepatocellular necrosis.
  3. Chronic Hepatocellular Disorders (3-E):
    • Mild elevation of ALT > AST with bilirubinemia is typical of chronic liver disease.
  4. Alcoholic Hepatitis (4-C):
    • Elevated AST ratio (>2) with low albumin is the hallmark of alcoholic liver injury.
  1. Intra-/Extrahepatic Cholestasis (5-B):
    • Elevated ALP (>4× normal) with normal albumin is indicative of cholestasis or biliary obstruction.

Key Takeaways:

  • Use ALT/AST ratios and levels to identify hepatocellular injuries.
  • Elevated ALP indicates cholestasis, while indirect hyperbilirubinemia points to unconjugated causes (e.g., Gilbert's syndrome or hemolysis).

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 337, page no: 2554.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with bilateral flank pain, lower back discomfort, and mild leg edema. He has a history of hypertension and has been on long-term hydralazine therapy. Imaging reveals a greyish, fibrotic plaque encasing the ureters and common iliac vessels in the lower lumbar region. His creatinine level is mildly elevated, and a biopsy shows active inflammation with collagen deposition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. Aortic aneurysm rupture: Typically presents with sudden severe pain and hypotension, not gradual onset with fibrotic changes.
  2. Retroperitoneal fibrosis: Correct. The development of a fibrotic mass that encases structures like the ureters, iliac vessels, and aorta is characteristic. Histology shows inflammation and collagen deposition.
  3. Chronic pyelonephritis: Associated more with recurrent UTIs, scarring, and changes in kidney structure, not widespread fibrosis.
  4. Pelvic lipomatosis: Refers to benign overgrowth of fatty tissue in the pelvic region, which does not involve inflammatory fibrotic changes like retroperitoneal fibrosis.

Retroperitoneal Fibrosis

  • rare disorder characterized by the formation of a fibrous mass in the retroperitoneum, often involving the ureters and great vessels.
  • Etiology:
    • Benign causes: Idiopathic (Ormond's disease), chronic inflammation, trauma, aortic aneurysm, retroperitoneal irritation by blood or urine extravasation.
  • Malignant causes: Secondary to lymphoma, metastatic cancers (especially from stomach, colon, breast, and prostate), carcinoid tumors, and drug-induced (e.g., methysergide, chemotherapeutic agents).
  • Clinical Features: Bilateral flank pain, lower back pain, lower limb edema, obstructive uropathy, and impaired renal function.
  • Management:
    • Medical: Steroids, immunosuppressants (e.g., azathioprine).
    • Surgical: Ureterolysis to relieve obstruction when necessary.

Key Points:

Idiopathic form is known as Ormond's disease. Can be associated with other fibromatoses like Dupuytren's contracture and Peyronie's disease.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 65, Page no: 1104.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with a fleshy, triangular growth on the nasal side of his right eye that has gradually extended towards the center of the cornea over the past year. He reports irritation and a foreign body sensation but no significant change in vision. The patient lives in a sunny, arid region and is concerned about the progression of this growth.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition if it is causing visual impairment?
questions.solution:
Pterygium is a common ocular surface disorder characterized by a benign growth of fibrovascular tissue extending from the conjunctiva onto the cornea. Key aspects include:

  1. Clinical Features:
    • Appearance: A triangular or wing-shaped, pinkish or fleshy growth that usually begins on the nasal side of the eye and can extend towards the center of the cornea.
    • Symptoms: Can include irritation, redness, foreign body sensation, dryness, and occasionally blurred vision if the growth encroaches on the visual axis.
  2. Etiology:
    • Environmental Factors: Prolonged exposure to UV light, wind, dust, and other environmental factors are major risk factors. Pterygium is often found in individuals living in sunny, arid environments.
    • Genetic Predisposition: There may be a genetic component as well, with a higher incidence in some families.
  1. Management:
    • Medical Treatment: Lubricating eye drops and anti-inflammatory medications to manage symptoms and inflammation.
    • Surgical Intervention: Indicated if the pterygium causes significant visual impairment or discomfort. Surgical removal is performed, often with the use of conjunctival autograft to reduce the risk of recurrence.

Option B) Surgical Excision with Conjunctival Autograft: This is the most appropriate treatment if the pterygium causes significant visual impairment or symptoms that affect the patient's quality of life. Surgical removal helps in addressing the growth, and using a conjunctival autograft reduces the risk of recurrence.

Option A) Topical Antihistamines: These are typically used for allergic conjunctivitis and are not effective for managing pterygium.

Option C) Oral Corticosteroids: While they can reduce inflammation, they are not a definitive treatment for pterygium and do not address the growth itself.

Option D) Artificial Tears and UV Protection: These can help manage symptoms and prevent further irritation but do not remove the growth or address visual impairment caused by pterygium

Reference: Kanski, J.J., & Bowling, B. (2011). Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. (7th ed.). Elsevier. (pp. 562-564)

questions.text: Match the Common Risk Factors with the Associated Lymphoma Types
questions.solution:
• pylori Infection: Strongly associated with gastric MALT lymphoma.
  • HTLV-1 Infection: Leads to Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma, common in endemic areas like Japan and the Caribbean.
  • EBV: Frequently seen in classical Hodgkin lymphoma, especially in immunocompromised settings.
  • HIV Infection: Increases risk for aggressive NHLs, including Burkitt lymphoma.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 109, Page no: 1358.

questions.text: A 60 year old male is incidentally found to have a renal cyst on imaging. Which Bosniak category indicates the following image?
questions.solution:
Bosniak Classification of Renal Cysts

Bosniak I: Simple cysts with thin walls, no septa, calcifications, or solid components; no enhancement with contrast.

Bosniak II: Cysts with a few thin septa or minor calcifications; no enhancement; typically benign and require no followup.

Bosniak IIF: Cysts with more septa or calcifications than Bosniak II, but still no enhancement; require followup imaging.

Bosniak III: Cysts with thickened, irregular walls or septa; may enhance with contrast; surgical evaluation recommended due to higher risk of malignancy.

Bosniak IV: Cysts with solid, enhancing components; high likelihood of malignancy; surgical resection usually required.

Option A: Bosniak I is Correct. This category represents simple renal cysts with a thin wall, no septa, calcifications, or solid components, and no enhancement.

Option B: Bosniak II is Incorrect. This category includes minimally complicated cysts with thin septa or small calcifications but no solid enhancing components.

Option C: Bosniak III is Incorrect. This category includes more complicated cysts with thickened or irregular walls/septa and requires further evaluation, often surgical.

Option D: Bosniak IV is Incorrect. This category represents cysts with solid enhancing components, indicative of malignancy.

Key Takeaway:

  • Bosniak classification helps determine the risk of malignancy in renal cysts.
  • Bosniak I cysts are simple and benign, requiring no further action.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 81, Page no: 1460

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with sudden onset of severe eye pain, decreased vision, and redness following recent cataract surgery. On examination, the patient has a hypopyon and vitreous opacities. Vitrectomy is performed, and cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism in this case, given the typical time frame and clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Endophthalmitis:

  1. Definition
    • Endophthalmitis is a severe, sight-threatening inflammation of the intraocular structures, primarily caused by infection. It involves both the anterior and posterior segments of the eye.
  2. Etiology
    • Most commonly results from postoperative infection (e.g., following cataract surgery, intravitreal injections).
    • Can also be caused by trauma (penetrating eye injury introducing pathogens) or endogenous spread (bloodborne infection from another body site, such as endocarditis or systemic fungal infection).
  3. Common Causative Organisms
    • Bacterial:
      • Coagulase-negative Staphylococci (most common in postoperative cases)
      • Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus spp., and Pseudomonas aeruginosa
    • Fungal:
      • Candida and Aspergillus species in endogenous fungal endophthalmitis, more common in immunocompromised individuals.
  1. Clinical Presentation
    • Severe eye pain
    • Rapidly progressive vision loss
    • Redness and photophobia
    • Hypopyon (pus in the anterior chamber)
    • Vitritis (inflammation of the vitreous, presenting as hazy media)
    • Swollen eyelids, corneal edema, and decreased intraocular pressure may also be seen.
  1. Diagnostic Workup
    • Clinical Examination: Findings include hypopyon, anterior chamber inflammation, vitritis, and reduced visual acuity.
    • Vitreous or Aqueous Tap: Samples taken for culture, Gram stain, and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to identify causative organisms.
  1. Treatment
    • Intravitreal Antibiotics: Direct injection into the vitreous to target infection. Common drugs include vancomycin (Gram-positive coverage) and ceftazidime (Gram-negative coverage).
    • Vitrectomy: Surgical removal of infected vitreous may be necessary in severe cases to clear the infection and improve outcomes.
  1. Prevention
  • Prophylactic antibiotics: Administered perioperatively in cataract surgery (usually intracameral or topical).
  • Sterile techniques during ocular procedures to reduce the risk of introducing infections.
  • Prompt management of ocular trauma to prevent infection.
  • Option A) Pseudomonas aeruginosa: This is a common bacterial pathogen responsible for post-surgical endophthalmitis, particularly within the first few weeks following cataract surgery. It is known for causing rapid onset, severe symptoms, and is associated with poor outcomes if not promptly treated.
  • Option B) Aspergillus flavus: A fungal organism, less commonly responsible for acute post-surgical endophthalmitis but may be considered in chronic or more atypical cases, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Option C) Herpes Simplex Virus: More often associated with herpetic keratitis or retinitis rather than acute endophthalmitis following cataract surgery.
  • Option D) Candida albicans: Typically causes endogenous endophthalmitis or in immunocompromised individuals, and is less common as a post-surgical pathogen compared to Pseudomonas

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 8th Edition, Chapter on Infectious Endophthalmitis, pp. 378-382.

questions.text: A 36 year old male patient with HIV developed visual problems since last month. On fundus examination it revealed the features shown in the given figure below. What is the Drug of choice for treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The fundus shows the characteristic features of CMV retinitis. Drug of choice for this condition is ganciclovir.

  • Ganciclovir is a drug of choice for cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections.
  • The dose-limiting toxicity of both zidovudine and ganciclovir is bone marrow suppression; therefore, anaemia and neutropenia can be predicted from the concurrent administration of ganciclovir and zidovudine.

Systemic toxicity of ganciclovir is high

  • Bone marrow
  • Depression
  • Rash
  • Fever
  • Vomiting
  • Neuropsychiatric disturbances

Therefore, use is restricted to prophylaxis and treatment of severe CMV infections (pneumonia/colitis/retinitis) which occur in immunocompromised (AIDS, transplant recipient) patients.

Key takeaway:

  • Ganciclovir is a drug of choice for cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections.

Topic:

  • Must Know
  • Ganciclovir

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no: 852.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old female presents to the clinic with a history of severe insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, and hypertriglyceridemia. Her physical examination reveals significant loss of subcutaneous fat with hepatomegaly. She has been started on leptin-replacement therapy.
Which of the following is NOT a benefit of leptin-replacement therapy in patients with generalized lipodystrophy?
questions.solution:
1. Improve glycemic control (Option A) - Correct benefit. Leptin-replacement therapy improves glycemic control in patients with generalized lipodystrophy by reducing insulin resistance and enhancing glucose uptake by peripheral tissues.
  2. Decrease fatty liver disease (Option B) - Correct benefit. Leptin therapy has been shown to reduce hepatic steatosis (fatty liver disease) in these patients by normalizing lipid metabolism and reducing fat accumulation in the liver.
  3. Increase circulating triglyceride levels (Option C) - Incorrect statement. Leptin therapy decreases circulating triglyceride levels, improving the lipid profile in patients with lipodystrophy. The loss of adipose tissue in lipodystrophy disrupts normal fat metabolism, but leptin therapy helps regulate lipid levels.
  4. Decrease insulin resistance (Option D) - Correct benefit. Leptin-replacement therapy helps reduce insulin resistance, which is a major contributor to the metabolic abnormalities seen in generalized lipodystrophy. This results in improved glucose metabolism and reduced hyperglycemia.

Key Takeaways:

  • Leptin-replacement therapy in patients with generalized lipodystrophy helps improve metabolic parameters by enhancing glycemic control, reducing fatty liver disease, lowering triglyceride levels, and decreasing insulin resistance.
  • This therapy addresses the deficiency of leptin, a hormone essential for regulating energy balance, lipid metabolism, and insulin sensitivity.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 403, "Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosis, Classification, and Pathophysiology," Page no: 3094.

questions.text: Nail hyperpigmentation is commonly encountered with the use of the following antiretroviral agent:
questions.solution:
• Chronic zidovudine administration has been associated with nail hyperpigmentation.

Unique Adverse Effect Profile of Zidovudine

  • Bone marrow suppression: anaemia and granulocytopenia
  • Skeletal muscle myopathy
  • Nail hyperpigmentation

Zidovudine is frequently used NRTI in the treatment of HIV infections.

It can also be used for the prophylaxis of needle stick injury patients and for the prevention of vertical transmission of HIV from mother to fetus.

Major adverse effect of zidovudine is bone marrow suppression leading to megaloblastic anemia, neutropenia and thrombocytopenia (ganciclovir should not be combined).

It is contraindicated in patient with Hb < 8g%.

It can also cause myopathy. Rifampicin increases the clearance of this drug.

Chronic administration is associated with lipodystrophy syndrome, nail hyperpigmentation and lipoatrophy.

Key takeaway:

  • Chronic zidovudine administration has been associated with nail hyperpigmentation.

Topic:

  • Good to Know
  • Zidovudine

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no: 861-862

questions.text: Match each gastrointestinal lesion with its characteristic pathologic finding.
questions.solution:
• Whipple's Disease (C): PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria are characteristic of Whipple's Disease, helping to distinguish it from other conditions.
  • Amyloidosis (D): Amyloid deposits in the lamina propria or submucosa are characteristic of amyloidosis and can be confirmed with Congo red staining.
  • Eosinophilic Gastroenteritis (A): Eosinophilic infiltration of the lamina propria and mucosa is the hallmark of eosinophilic gastroenteritis.
  • Celiac Disease (B): Villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and mononuclear infiltrate are classic findings in celiac disease, which is also associated with gluten sensitivity.
  • Intestinal Lymphangiectasia (E): Dilated lymphatics and clubbed villi are characteristic findings in intestinal lymphangiectasia, often leading to protein-losing enteropathy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Whipple's Disease: PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria.
  • Amyloidosis: Amyloid deposits detected with Congo red staining.
  • Eosinophilic Gastroenteritis: Eosinophilic infiltration in the lamina propria and mucosa.
  • Celiac Disease: Villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia.
  • Intestinal Lymphangiectasia: Dilated lymphatics and clubbed villi.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter on Gastrointestinal Disorders.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with symptoms of vaginal discharge, itching, and discomfort. A wet mount examination reveals motile protozoa with a characteristic "jerky" movement. The per speculum examinatory finding is given below,Which of the following is the causative agent of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Trichomonas vaginalis is a pear shaped protozoa with 1 nuclei and 5 flagella .

It causes vaginitis in females - frothy green colour,foul smelling discharge ,transmitted via sexual contact (as it cannot exist outside human body )

Strawberry Cervix

On wet mount - Trophozoites are seen. There are NO CYST forms.

Treatment:

Recommended Regimen for Trichomoniasis Among Women. Metronidazole 500 mg 2 times/day for 7 days.

  • Recommended Regimen for Trichomoniasis Among Men. Metronidazole 2 g orally in a single dose.
  • Alternative Regimen for Women and Men. Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose.

A) Giardia lamblia: Incorrect. Giardia lamblia causes giardiasis, which typically presents with gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhoea and abdominal pain, not with genital symptoms.

B) Trichomonas vaginalis: Correct. Trichomonas vaginalis is the causative agent of trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection (STI) that often presents with symptoms including vaginal discharge, itching, and discomfort. The characteristic motile protozoa observed under the microscope confirm this diagnosis.

C) Plasmodium falciparum: Incorrect. Plasmodium falciparum is a protozoan parasite that causes malaria, which presents with symptoms such as fever, chills, and sweats, not genital symptoms.

D) Entamoeba histolytica: Incorrect. Entamoeba histolytica is responsible for amoebic dysentery or amoebiasis, which typically causes gastrointestinal symptoms such as dysentery and abdominal pain.

Key Takeaway: Trichomonas vaginalis is the protozoan parasite responsible for trichomoniasis, characterized by symptoms such as vaginal discharge and itching, and can be identified by its motile appearance in a wet mount examination.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Trichomoniasis. CDC Trichomoniasis

questions.text: What is the characteristic pattern observed in given portion B (RED ARROW) of electrophoresis image?
questions.solution:
Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death that occurs in a controlled and regulated manner to remove damaged, unnecessary, or harmful cells without causing inflammation.

Key Features:

  1. Cell Shrinkage: Cells shrink and condense.
  2. DNA Fragmentation: The cell's DNA is broken down.
  3. Formation of Apoptotic Bodies: The cell breaks into small, membrane-bound fragments.
  4. Phagocytosis: Apoptotic bodies are engulfed and removed by neighbouring cells or immune cells.

Shown picture is of DNA FRAGMENTATION on agar gel electrophoresis.

Portion A: Normal cells

Portion B: Step ladder pattern

Portion C: Smear pattern

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Apoptosis is characterized by a ladder-like pattern of DNA fragmentation due to cleavage by caspases and endonucleases.

Smear-like pattern can occur in both necrosis and apoptosis but is less specific.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 37.

questions.text: Ms. Handrew presents with occasional palpitations. Her rhythm strip (Figure IV-56) is consistent with which of the following rhythms?
questions.solution:
• The rhythm strip shows multifocal premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), identifiable by the presence of PVCs with different morphologies, indicating multiple ectopic foci.
  • Atrial flutter would present with a characteristic sawtooth pattern.
  • Nonsustained ventricular tachycardia would show a brief run of wide-complex tachycardia lasting less than 30 seconds.
  • Sustained ventricular tachycardia lasts more than 30 seconds or requires termination.

Key Takeaways:

  • Multifocal PVCs indicate ectopic activity from multiple ventricular foci, often seen in patients with underlying cardiac disease.
  • Differentiating PVCs from sustained arrhythmias like VT is important for appropriate management.

Topic: Ventricular Arrhythmias, Premature Ventricular Contractions, ECG

Difficulty: Must Know

questions.text: Disease caused by this vector
questions.solution:
Dengue is transmitted primarily by mosquitoes of the genus Aedes, particularly Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

  1. Distinctive Black and White Pattern: Aedes mosquitoes have white markings on their legs and a lyre-shaped pattern of white scales on the upper surface of their thorax.
  2. Daytime Biters: Aedes mosquitoes are most active during the day, especially early morning and late afternoon.
  3. Eggs Laid in Dry Areas: They lay eggs in containers or areas that can later hold water, but the eggs can survive for long periods without water.
  4. Vector for Diseases: They are known carriers of diseases like dengue, Zika, chikungunya, and yellow fever.
  5. Breeding in Clean Water: Aedes mosquitoes breed in clean, stagnant water found in containers, tires, and pots.
  6. Short Flight Range: They typically have a limited flight range of 50-100 meters from their breeding sites.

Option (a): Malaria is caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Plasmodium, and it is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes.

Option (b): The primary vectors for JEV are mosquitoes of the genus Culex. Specifically, Culex tritaeniorhynchus is the main vector in many areas.

Option (d): Kala Azar is transmitted through the bite of infected female sandflies, particularly those of the genus Phlebotomus

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Dengue is transmitted primarily by mosquitoes of the genus Aedes, particularly Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-15, Page no: 835-840.

questions.text: Examine the provided electron microscope image. What virus is shown?
questions.solution:
• It is a is filamentous with a helical structure, appearing as long, thread-like particles.
  • Option A) Ebola Virus: Ebola Virus is filamentous with a helical structure, appearing as long, thread-like particles.
  • Option B) Dengue Virus: Dengue Virus particles are spherical with a smooth surface, not filamentous.
  • Option C) SARS-CoV-2: SARS-CoV-2 has a spherical shape with spike proteins but does not have the filamentous structure depicted.
  • Option D) Rotavirus: Rotavirus is characterized by a wheel-like (or double-layered) structure and is not filamentous.

Key Takeaway: Ebola Virus is distinct due to its filamentous, thread-like appearance, which is essential for its identification.

Reference: For more information on the Ebola Virus, refer to the CDC: CDC - Ebola Virus

questions.text: 11-Year-old Village Boy is presented with severe tooth pain and Sensitivity to Hot & Cold. On examination, Dental Caries has been found as shown in above images in multiple teeth. Village do not have community water supply. Identify the correct statement regarding nutrient Deficiency this patient is suffering.

  • Option B): Fluoride replaces the hydroxyl group of Hydroxylapatite forming fluorapatite that is more resistant to the enamel dissolving acid produced by mouth bacteria.
  • Fluoride deficiency, particularly in children, can lead to an increased risk of dental caries due to weakened enamel, allowing bacterial acids to penetrate and damage the tooth structure. This report discusses a case of fluoride deficiency leading to widespread dental decay.

Option A & D) Fluoride is added in water to prevent dental carries. Higher levels can cause skeletal fluorosis (Osteoporosis and calcification of tendons and ligaments)

Option C) Post Translational modification of collagen is required for cross linking of collagen fibers. It helps in formation of Interchain hydrogen bonds that stabilize the triple helix structure. It requires presence of Vitamin C and deficiency leads to scurvy.

questions.text: Chemical used to kill the larva is?
questions.solution:
The chemical used to kill the larvae of Anopheles mosquitoes is: a. Paris green

  • Paris green (copper(II) acetoarsenite) is an insecticide specifically used for larvicidal action against Anopheles mosquito larvae, which are responsible for the transmission of malaria.
  • DDT is primarily used as an adulticide, targeting adult mosquitoes.
  • Abate (Temephos) is another larvicide used for controlling mosquito larvae, but it is not as commonly associated with Anopheles specifically as Paris green.
  • Malathion is an organophosphate insecticide used against adult mosquitoes and other pests but is not primarily used for larval control of Anopheles.

Therefore, Paris green is the most appropriate answer.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Paris green (copper(II) acetoarsenite) is an insecticide specifically used for larvicidal action against Anopheles mosquito larvae, which are responsible for the transmission of malaria

choices.text: Stone Fragments in a renal stone
Multiple stone fragments in the ureter

questions.text: A 35 year old male with a history of recent extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) presents with flank pain and fever. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Steinstrasse (Stone Street)

  • Steinstrasse refers to the alignment of multiple stone fragments in the ureter, a common complication postESWL. It can cause ureteral obstruction, leading to pain, infection, and hydronephrosis.
  • Symptoms: Flank pain, fever, and signs of urinary obstruction following ESWL.
  • Diagnosis: Imaging, typically noncontrast CT or X Ray, showing a chain of stone fragments within the ureter.
  • Management: Observation if asymptomatic, medical expulsive therapy, or intervention (ureteroscopy or additional ESWL) if symptomatic or obstructing.

Option A : Stone Fragments in Kidney is an incorrect Option. It Refers to Ureter.

Option B : Stone formation in the urethra is Incorrect. Steinstrasse refers to the ureter, not the urethra.

Option C : Multiple stone fragments in the ureter are Correct. "Steinstrasse," meaning "stone street," refers to a condition where multiple stone fragments align in the ureter following ESWL, potentially causing obstruction and symptoms.

Option D : Bilateral hydronephrosis is Incorrect. Steinstrasse is a unilateral condition affecting the ureter and does not cause bilateral hydronephrosis.

Key Takeaway:

  • Steinstrasse is a post ESWL complication characterised by stone fragments lining up in the ureter.
  • It may cause pain and obstruction, requiring medical or surgical intervention.

Reference:

  • Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 82, Pages 1476

Paul Bunnell test is positive. Which of the following condition is not associated with this causative agent?
questions.solution:
• Symptoms + hemorrhagic petechiae at the junction of soft and hard palate + positive Paul Bunnell test all are suggestive of Infectious mononucleosis. The causative agent is EBV.

Conditions associated with EBV are:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Burkitt's lymphoma
  • Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative disorder
  • HLH syndrome
  • Alice in wonderland syndrome

choices.text: Subepithelial corneal deposits with a hazy appearance
Corneal opacification with a central "corneal scar"

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with night blindness, dry eyes, and conjunctival xerosis. On examination, there is a corneal ulcer with a characteristic finding present on the conjunctiva. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding on slit-lamp examination in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Corneal opacification with a central "corneal scar" (C) is a key finding in advanced vitamin A deficiency. This occurs due to severe dry eye and corneal damage leading to scarring and opacification. Vitamin A deficiency can lead to keratomalacia, which results in corneal ulceration and subsequent scarring.

Vitamin A Deficiency:

  • Description: Vitamin A deficiency leads to a range of ocular problems due to the critical role of vitamin A in maintaining epithelial cell health and vision.
  • Symptoms:
    • Night blindness (nyctalopia): Difficulty seeing in low light.
    • Xerophthalmia: Dry eyes due to reduced tear production.
    • Bitot's spots: White, foamy spots on the conjunctiva due to keratinization of conjunctival epithelium.
    • Corneal damage: Keratomalacia, which can lead to corneal scarring and blindness.
  • Clinical Findings:
    • Slit-lamp Examination: Dry, rough conjunctiva, Bitot’s spots, and corneal opacification/scarring.
    • Fundoscopic Examination: Night blindness and reduced visual acuity.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serum Vitamin A Levels: Low levels confirm deficiency.
    • Clinical History and Examination: Typical findings as described.
  • Treatment:
    • Vitamin A Supplementation: Oral or intramuscular vitamin A.
    • Management of Complications: Treatment of corneal ulcers and dry eye with lubricants.

Dosage of Vitamin A for Treatment of Deficiency:

  1. For Children:
    • Mild to Moderate Deficiency:
      • Oral Dosage: 100,000 IU (30 mg) once daily for 2 days, then 50,000 IU (15 mg) daily for 14 days.
    • Severe Deficiency:
      • Oral Dosage: 200,000 IU (60 mg) once daily for 2 days, then 100,000 IU (30 mg) daily for 14 days.
    • Note: Doses may be adjusted based on the child's age and weight.
  2. For Adults:
    • Oral Dosage: 50,000 IU (15 mg) once daily for 1-2 weeks, followed by 25,000 IU (7.5 mg) daily for several weeks.
    • Severe Deficiency:
      • Oral Dosage: 100,000 IU (30 mg) once daily for 1-2 days, then 50,000 IU (15 mg) daily for 14 days.
  3. Pregnant Women with Deficiency:
    • Oral Dosage: 10,000 IU (3 mg) once daily for several weeks, but dosing should be carefully monitored to avoid toxicity.
  4. For Severe Cases:
    • Intramuscular Injection: In cases of acute or severe deficiency with complications like corneal ulcers, a single dose of 200,000 IU (60 mg) may be administered intramuscularly, followed by oral supplementation.

General Recommendations:

  • Monitoring: Regular monitoring of vitamin A levels and clinical response is essential.
  • Safety: High doses of vitamin A should be used cautiously to avoid toxicity. Long-term high-dose supplementation should be avoided unless medically supervised.

Other options

  • Corneal neovascularization with dendritic ulcers (A) is more indicative of herpes simplex keratitis, not vitamin A deficiency.
  • Subepithelial corneal deposits with a hazy appearance (B) is characteristic of Wilson's disease or other types of corneal degeneration, not vitamin A deficiency.
  • Corneal thinning and a "band-shaped" deposit (D) refers to band keratopathy, which is usually associated with chronic ocular surface disease, not vitamin A deficiency.

Reference:

  • World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines on vitamin A supplementation.
  • Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Pages 378-382.

choices.text: Cardio embolism causing obstruction of cutaneous vessel resulting in skin infarct

questions.text: A diagnosed case of CKD on WARFARIN for atrial Fibrillation presents with painful nodule on abdomen that is followed by progressive Narrowing of the abdominal skin. The Image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Calciphylaxis is a severe condition primarily affecting patients with advanced CKD, often presenting with painful livedo reticularis and subcutaneous nodules that progress to ischemic necrosis.
  • This condition is characterized by extensive vascular and soft tissue calcification, leading to vascular occlusion. It is especially concerning in areas like the abdomen, thighs, and legs.
  • Warfarin therapy is a notable risk factor for calciphylaxis in dialysis patients as it reduces the activation of matrix GLA protein, which normally helps prevent vascular calcification.
  • Management of calciphylaxis involves:
    • Discontinuation of warfarin to halt further progression.
    • Treatments such as hyperbaric oxygen therapy and IV thiosulfate to promote healing and reduce vascular calcification.
    • Use of calcimimetic agents like cinacalcet can enhance sensitivity of parathyroid cells to calcium, helping regulate phosphate and calcium levels, which may prevent calciphylaxis.
  • Why Not Other Options:
    • A. Vasculitis: Presents with systemic symptoms and organ involvement, not just localized nodules and skin changes.
    • B. Cardioembolism causing obstruction of cutaneous vessels resulting in skin infarct: While it could cause skin infarction, it would not typically present with livedo reticularis or nodules.
    • C. Necrotizing infection: Usually accompanied by systemic signs of infection (fever, increased WBC), which are not noted in this case.
  • Key Takeaways:
    • Calciphylaxis is a devastating complication of advanced CKD, presenting with painful nodules and skin necrosis, particularly in patients on warfarin.
    • Effective management includes discontinuation of warfarin, use of hyperbaric oxygen, IV thiosulfate, and consideration of cinacalcet to manage calcium and phosphate levels.

Tags:

Topic: Chronic kidney disease

Type: Must Know

Difficulty: High

PYQ: NEET PG 2020

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2313

choices.text: Collecting cervical cells for a Pap smear

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is primarily used for which of the following purposes in gynecology?
questions.solution:
The image shows an Ayre's spatula, a wooden or plastic device used to scrape cells from the ectocervix and transformation zone during a Pap smear for cytological examination.

OPTION A: Measuring cervical length:

Cervical length is typically measured using transvaginal ultrasound, especially in pregnancy to assess the risk of preterm birth. Tools like a cervical probe or calipers in ultrasound machines are used for this purpose. Ayre's spatula does not have the capability to measure cervical length, as it is specifically designed for cell collection rather than measurement.

OPTION B. Collecting cervical cells for a Pap smear:

Ayre's spatula is a tool specifically designed for collecting exfoliated cells from the ectocervix and the transformation zone during a Pap smear. It is a wooden or plastic device with a flat blade and a pointed end, which allows gentle scraping of the cervical surface to collect cells for cytological evaluation. This is the primary purpose of Ayre's spatula, making this the correct answer.

OPTION C. Inserting an intrauterine device (IUD):

IUD insertion requires specialized tools such as a tenaculum, uterine sound, and an IUD inserter. Ayre's spatula is not used in this procedure, as it does not aid in the insertion or positioning of the IUD.

OPTION D. Performing endometrial biopsy:

Endometrial biopsy involves using a specialized device, such as a Pipelle's device or a curette, which is designed to enter the uterine cavity and obtain a sample of the endometrial tissue. Ayre's spatula is not used for this purpose because it cannot access the uterine cavity or collect endometrial tissue.

Key takeaway: Ayre's spatula is specifically used for collecting cells from the cervix during a Pap smear. It is designed to scrape the surface of the ectocervix and the transformation zone to obtain an adequate sample for cytological examination, which helps in the detection of precancerous changes, cervical dysplasia, or cervical cancer.

Fig. A. Ayre spatula(ectocervix); B. Cytobrush (for endocervix); C. Cervex brush(Ectocervix, endocervix and transformation zone)

Type: Must know

Topic: Pap smear

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Page no. 633

questions.text: Identify the structure being palpated in the given image :
questions.solution:
Palmaris longus overview -

  1. Origin:
    • Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon).
  2. Insertion:
    • Palmar aponeurosis and the flexor retinaculum of the hand.
  3. Action:
    • Flexes the wrist (weak flexor).
    • Tenses the palmar aponeurosis, aiding in gripping actions.
  4. Innervation:
    • Median nerve (C7, C8).
  5. Blood Supply:
    • Ulnar artery, with contributions from the anterior branch of the median artery.
  6. Palpation :
    • Hand is flexed from wrist joint after touching the thumb and little finger as shown in the image, palmaris longus tendon will become prominent near the wrist crease.

Option A - Radial artery can be palpated as a pulsating structure along the volar surface of radial side of radius bone near the wrist

Option B - Median nerve lies deep beneath the flexor tendons in the carpal tunnel and cannot be palpated

Option C - FCR tendon becomes prominent upon flexion and radial deviation at wrist joint and lies radial to palmaris longus.

Note: The palmaris longus is a superficial muscle in the anterior compartment of the forearm, and it is absent in about 10-20% of the population. Due to its limited functional importance, it is often used as a tendon graft in surgeries.

General orthopaedics/ general anatomy/ May to know

choices.text: Eradication strategy- catch up, keep up, follow up
Vaccine started at 9 months of age
Killed vaccine given by intramuscular route

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to clinic by her mother saying that child is having fever, running nose, and difficulty in swallowing. on examination, you noticed a lesion given in the image. All are true for given condition except:
questions.solution:
Based on the presentation of a 3-year-old child with fever, runny nose, difficulty swallowing, and Koplik's spots, which indicate measles

  1. Viral disease which is vaccine preventable - True. Measles is a viral disease and is preventable with the measles vaccine.
  2. Eradication strategy - catch up, keep up, follow up - True. This strategy is used in vaccination programs to ensure that children receive their vaccines on time and address missed doses.
  3. Vaccine started at 9 months of age - Partially True. The routine MMR vaccine is typically given at 12-15 months of age, though it can be administered as early as 6-9 months in outbreak situations or high-risk areas.
  4. Killed vaccine given by intramuscular route - False. The MMR vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, not a killed vaccine, and it is given by the subcutaneous route, not intramuscularly.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Child with fever, runny nose, difficulty swallowing, and Koplik's spots, indicate measles.

Reference: Immunization_Handbook_for_Medical_Officers 2017, MOHFW, GOI, unit no.-04, Page No -19-26.

choices.text: Decreases the deposition of drug that impinges on oropharynx
Increases the delivery of drug to lower airways
Increases the velocity of drug particles entering the upper airways
Decreases the systemic absorption of drugs

questions.text: All are correct about the below device used along with pMDI except:
questions.solution:
• The given image is of a spacer device with a face mask.
  • The spacer device is used between the PMDI (pressurized metered dose inhaler) and the patient.
  • Spacers reduce the velocity of particles entering the upper airways and the size of particles by allowing the evaporation of liquid propellant.
  • Children as young as 3 years of age are able to use a spacer device fitted with a mask.
  • Most asthma patients are now maintained on inhaled medication only. Aerosols are of two types:

(i) Use drug in solution: pressurized metered dose inhaler (MDI), nebulizers.

(ii) Use drug as dry powder (DPI) spinhaler, rotahaler.

  • Pressurized metered dose inhalers use hydrofluoroalkane (HFA) propellants and deliver a specified dose of the drug in spray form per actuation
  • A large volume 'spacer' (chamber interposed between the inhaler and the patient's mouth) can be used to improve drug delivery by obviating the need for precise coordination.
  • Moreover, larger particles settle on the walls of the spacer reducing the fraction that deposits in the throat and is later swallowed.
  • Local complications (candidiasis with inhaled steroids) as well as systemic exposure are reduced.

Option A & B: The above actions reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drug inhaled into lower airways

Option D: By reducing oropharyngeal deposition, the systemic absorption is also decreased

Key takeaway

  • Large volume 'spacer' (chamber interposed between the inhaler and the patient's mouth) can be used to improve drug delivery by obviating the need for precise coordination.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 252

questions.text:
A patient with recent antibiotic use presents with severe diarrhoea. The stool sample shows Gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria with spores.

Which bacterial pathogen is most likely causing the symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Produces toxins A and B, which damage enterocytes. Both toxins lead to watery diarrhoea- pseudomembranous colitis.
  • Often 2° to antibiotic use, especially clindamycin, ampicillin, cephalosporins, fluoroquinolones; associated with PPIs.
  • Causes Fulminant infection: toxic megacolon, ileus, shock.

A) Clostridium difficile: Gram-positive rods with spores, commonly associated with antibiotic-associated diarrhoea, pseudo membranous colitis.

B) Clostridium tetani: Gram-positive rods but not typically spore-forming in stool samples.

C) Bacillus cereus: Gram-positive rods, but not primarily associated with spore-forming diarrhoea.

D) Bacillus anthracis: Gram-positive rods, but associated with anthrax rather than diarrhoea.

Key Takeaway: Clostridium difficile is identified by its Gram-positive, spore-forming rods, especially in the context of recent antibiotic use.

Reference: CDC Clostridium difficile

choices.text: It is always a cellulitis and not an abscess
It involves the submandibular and sublingual glands
It spreads through tissue spaces and not through lymphatic.

questions.text: A 30 year old female patient presented with complain of pain and swelling over floor of mouth, bilateral submandibular region. The entire region was tender and inflamed. Patient gave past history of tooth extraction. Patient also has uncontrolled diabetes. Picture given below. All of the following are diagnostic criteria for this condition except?
questions.solution:
• In the above condition the swelling is involving bilateral submandibular region. It developed following dental extraction.
  • Patient also has uncontrolled diabetes. It is involving floor of mouth. All these points leads to diagnosis of Ludwig's abscess.

There are four Goldring s criteria to diagnose Ludwig's abscess.

  1. It is always cellulitis and not an abscess. If an abscess is present it is known as submandibular abscess and not Ludwig's angina.
  2. It is always bilateral
  3. It spreads through tissue space and not through lymphatic.
  4. It does not involve the submandibular and sublingual glands.

Management: Incision and drainage A horizontal incision is kept 2 to 3 cm below the lower border of mandible extending from angle of mandible to the other.

Antibiotics covering both Aerobes and anaerobes.

Tag1: pharynx and oral cavity. Deep neck space abscess

questions.text: Which of the following is the most critical factor in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Fournier's Gangrene:

  • Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive necrotizing fasciitis of the perineal, genital, and perianal regions. It is a surgical emergency characterised by widespread tissue necrosis.

Causes:

  • Polymicrobial Infection: Typically caused by a mix of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria, including Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, and Clostridium species.
  • Risk Factors: Diabetes, immunosuppression, obesity, and chronic alcohol use.

Clinical Features:

  • Severe Pain: Sudden onset of intense pain in the perineum, often disproportionate to physical findings.
  • Swelling and Crepitus: Due to gas formation by anaerobic bacteria.
  • Skin Discoloration: Rapid progression from erythema to necrosis, with overlying skin turning dark or black.
  • Systemic Toxicity: Fever, tachycardia, hypotension, and signs of septic shock.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical: High index of suspicion based on rapid progression and characteristic features.
  • Imaging: diagnosis should not be delayed for imaging.
  • Laboratory: Blood cultures and wound cultures help guide antibiotic therapy.

Management:

  • Early Surgical Debridement: The cornerstone of treatment. All necrotic tissue must be removed to control the spread of infection.
  • High Dose Intravenous Antibiotics: Broad Spectrum antibiotics are initiated immediately, often including coverage for Gram Positive, Gram-negative, and anaerobic organisms.
  • Supportive Care: Includes fluid resuscitation, hemodynamic support, and management of any underlying conditions (e.g., diabetes).
  • Adjunct Therapies: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be used to inhibit anaerobic bacteria and promote wound healing.

Prognosis:

  • Mortality Rate: High, especially if diagnosis and treatment are delayed.
  • Complications: Sepsis, multiorgan failure, and extensive tissue loss requiring reconstructive surgery.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) High Dose intravenous antibiotics: Essential but secondary to surgical intervention.

Option B) Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: An adjunct therapy, not the primary intervention.

Option C) Early surgical debridement: The most critical factor in managing Fournier's gangrene. Prompt removal of necrotic tissue is essential to control the spread of infection and improve survival.

Option D) Fluid resuscitation: Important for stabilising the patient but not sufficient without surgical intervention.

Key Takeaways:

Fournier's Gangrene: Early surgical debridement is the most critical factor in management. It must be combined with aggressive antibiotic therapy and supportive care to reduce mortality.

Reference:

Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter -4, Pages -58

questions.text:
A patient with pneumonia presents. The Gram stain image shows a poor Gram stain result with slender, Gram-negative rods, best identified by special stains or culture methods.

Which bacterial pathogen is most likely causing this pneumonia?
questions.solution:
• Gram negative rod, stains poorly, hence silver stain is used. Grow on charcoal yeast extract medium with iron and cysteine. Detected by presence of antigen in urine. Labs may show hyponatremia and elevated transaminases.
  • Aerosol transmission from environmental water source (eg, air conditioning systems, hot water tanks). Outbreaks associated with cruise ships, nursing homes. No person-to-person transmission.
  • Treatment: macrolide or quinolone

Explanation:

  1. Legionella pneumophila: Slender, Gram-negative rods that may not be well-stained by Gram stain; best identified by special stains or culture.
  2. Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Lacks a cell wall, so does not gram stain well; diagnosed by other methods.
  3. Chlamydia pneumoniae: Intracellular pathogen, does not stain well with Gram stain.
  4. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Gram-positive diplococci, not slender rods.

Key Takeaway: Legionella pneumophila is identified by its slender, Gram-negative rods and requires special stains or culture for definitive identification.

Reference: CDC Legionnaires' Disease

questions.text:
A patient presents with a skin lesion that has a black eschar. The Gram stain image shows large, Gram-positive rods with square ends and a characteristic "boxcar" appearance.

Which bacterial species is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Gram-positive rods with a "boxcar" appearance and large size, associated with cutaneous anthrax and a black eschar.

Explanation:

  1. Bacillus anthracis: Gram-positive rods with a "boxcar" appearance and large size, associated with cutaneous anthrax and a black eschar.
  2. Bacillus cereus: Gram-positive rods but not with the characteristic "boxcar" appearance.
  3. Clostridium botulinum: Gram-positive rods but typically associated with botulism, not the "boxcar" appearance.
  4. Clostridium perfringens: Gram-positive rods but typically associated with gas gangrene, not the "boxcar" appearance.

Key Takeaway: Bacillus anthracis is characterized by large, Gram-positive rods with a "boxcar" appearance, often associated with cutaneous anthrax.

Reference: CDC Bacillus anthracis

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents with progressive difficulty in walking and frequent falls over the past year. She also reports changes in her speech, which has become slurred, and difficulty looking down. She has no history of tremors. On examination, she shows marked postural instability, slow vertical saccades, and poor response to levodopa therapy. Her gait is unsteady, with an inability to maintain balance when standing still. MRI is shown below

Which of the following diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (Progressive Supranuclear Palsy - PSP):

  • Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) is characterized by early postural instability, frequent falls, supranuclear gaze palsy (particularly affecting vertical eye movements), and a poor response to levodopa. The early onset of gait disturbance and lack of tremor further distinguish PSP from idiopathic Parkinson's Disease (PD).
  • Midbrain Atrophy: Imaging findings of midbrain atrophy, often described as a "hummingbird sign," are suggestive of PSP. These changes are not typical in PD and support the diagnosis of PSP.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A (Parkinson's Disease): PD typically presents with asymmetric tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and good initial response to levodopa. Postural instability usually appears later in the disease course.
  • Option C (Multiple System Atrophy - MSA): MSA can present with autonomic symptoms, parkinsonism, or cerebellar ataxia, but it lacks the supranuclear gaze palsy seen in PSP. MSA patients also commonly show severe autonomic dysfunction early on.
  • Option D (Corticobasal Degeneration - CBD): CBD often presents with asymmetric motor features such as alien limb phenomenon, apraxia, and cortical sensory loss. Gaze palsy and frequent falls are less common in CBD compared to PSP.
  • Option E (Essential Tremor): Essential tremor typically presents with a postural or action tremor and lacks the bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability associated with parkinsonian syndromes.

Key Takeaways:

  • PSP is a form of atypical parkinsonism, with early postural instability, frequent falls, supranuclear gaze palsy, and midbrain atrophy on imaging.
  • Parkinson's Disease usually has a good response to levodopa, asymmetric motor symptoms, and rest tremor, which are not seen in PSP.
  • Differentiating atypical parkinsonian syndromes is key, as they have distinct clinical courses, responses to therapy, and imaging findings.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, 435, pg 3389

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM) after a prenatal ultrasound revealed a multicystic mass in the lung. Postnatal imaging confirms the diagnosis. What is the best management strategy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Congenital Lung Malformations

Types:

  • Congenital Cystic Adenomatoid Malformation (CCAM): A multicystic mass of abnormal lung tissue that can vary in size and appearance.
  • Bronchopulmonary Sequestration: Nonfunctioning lung tissue that does not communicate with the bronchial tree and has an abnormal blood supply.
  • Congenital Lobar Emphysema: Overexpansion of a lobe of the lung, leading to compression of adjacent lung tissue.

Clinical Features:

  • Prenatal Diagnosis: Many cases of CCAM and other pulmonary malformations are detected on prenatal ultrasound.
  • Asymptomatic at Birth: Most infants with CCAM are asymptomatic at birth.
  • Respiratory Distress: Some may present with respiratory distress if the lesion is large or if there is associated hydrops fetalis.

Diagnosis:

  • Prenatal Ultrasound: Detects cystic or solid lung lesions.
  • Postnatal Imaging (Chest X-ray, CT Scan): Confirms the diagnosis and assesses the size and extent of the lesion

Management:

  • Observation and Follow-up: Asymptomatic infants are often managed conservatively with regular imaging to monitor the lesion.
  • Surgical Resection: Indicated if the lesion is symptomatic, if there is rapid growth, or if there is a risk of malignancy (e.g., in CPAM/CCAM).
  • Antibiotics: Used if there is evidence of infection in the lesion, though this is rare.

Complications:

  • Respiratory Distress: Can occur if the lesion is large enough to compress normal lung tissue.
  • Infection: Rare, but possible in cystic lesions.
  • Malignant Transformation: Rarely, like pleuropulmonary blastoma.

Option A : Immediate surgical resection is not always necessary immediately after birth. Many cases of CCAM are asymptomatic at birth and may be managed conservatively.

Option B : Observation and followup is Correct. For asymptomatic infants with CCAM, observation and regular followup are recommended, with surgery considered if symptoms develop or if the lesion grows.

Option C : Antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a secondary infection.

Option D : Corticosteroids have no role in the management of CCAM.

Key Takeaways:

  • CCAM is often managed with observation and follow up, with surgery reserved for symptomatic cases or lesions with rapid growth.
  • Regular imaging is important to monitor for changes in the lesion that may require intervention.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 18 ,page 272

questions.text:
A 55-year-old patient with a history of immunosuppression presents with pulmonary symptoms and skin lesions. The biopsy image shows branching, filamentous bacteria that are weakly acid-fast.

Based on the microscopic image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Nocardia is an aerobe, catalase positive and weakly acid fast bacteria.
  • Characterized by branching, filamentous bacteria.
  • It causes disease similar to tuberculosis but with PPD negative.

Explanation:

  1. Nocardiosis: Characterized by branching, filamentous bacteria that are weakly acid-fast. Nocardia species are known for these features.
  2. Aspergillosis: Caused by Aspergillus species, which have septate hyphae with acute-angle branching, not filamentous bacteria
  3. Actinomycosis: Caused by Actinomyces species, which show branching filaments but do not have the weak acid-fast characteristic of Nocardia.
  4. Mycobacteriosis: Caused by Mycobacterium species, which are strongly acid-fast rods, differing from the weakly acid-fast nature of Nocardia.

Key Takeaway: Nocardia infections are identified by weakly acid-fast, branching filamentous bacteria. This is important for distinguishing them from other filamentous infections.

Reference: CDC Nocardiosis Overview

questions.text: A 10-year-old patient presents with acute onset of eyelid swelling, redness, and pain around the eye, along with fever and limited eye movement. A CT scan reveals orbital swelling and possible involvement of the ethmoid sinus. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the tissues surrounding the eye, including the eyelids, orbital fat, and muscles. It is a serious condition that requires prompt medical attention.

  • Etiology:
    • Typically caused by bacterial infections, most commonly by Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus species.
    • Can also be a complication of sinus infections, especially from the ethmoid or maxillary sinuses.
  • Symptoms:
    • Rapidly progressive swelling of the eyelids and surrounding tissues.
    • Redness and warmth in the affected area.
    • Painful eye movements and possible reduced vision.
    • Fever and systemic symptoms may also be present.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical evaluation and history.
    • Imaging studies, such as CT scan or MRI, to assess the extent of infection and rule out other conditions.
    • Laboratory tests to identify the causative organism and determine antibiotic sensitivity.
  • Treatment:
    • Prompt administration of intravenous antibiotics to cover common pathogens.
    • Surgical intervention may be necessary to drain abscesses or remove any infected tissue if there is no improvement with antibiotics alone.
  • Complications:
    • Can lead to serious complications like vision loss, orbital abscess, or even meningitis if not treated promptly.

Options A and B are inadequate for the severity of this condition and do not address the potential need for surgical intervention.

Option D is inappropriate as orbital cellulitis requires immediate treatment to prevent serious complications.

Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 22nd Edition, Section IV, Chapter 19, The Orbit and Ocular Adnexa, p. 214.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with redness, swelling, and warmth of her left breast. The symptoms developed over a few weeks, and she noticed a peau d'orange appearance but no distinct lump. A core biopsy shows invasive ductal lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC)

  • Inflammatory carcinoma: peau d'orange and redness involving >1/3rd of the surface of the breast with or without a breast lump
  • Pathology: Inflammatory breast cancer involves dermal lymphatic invasion, leading to rapid onset of erythema, warmth, and edema of the breast without a discrete lump.
  • Diagnosis: Primarily clinical; confirmed by biopsy showing carcinoma cells in the dermal lymphatics.
  • Imaging: Mammography may show skin thickening, but no mass may be present.
  • Treatment: Multimodality approach-neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, and radiation. Trastuzumab for HER2-positive tumors; endocrine therapy for ER-positive tumors.
  • Prognosis: Poorer compared to other breast cancers due to its aggressive nature. Relapse-free survival is about 50% with aggressive treatment.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. Mastitis presents with similar inflammatory signs but is often associated with breastfeeding and infection. It typically responds to antibiotics, unlike IBC.

Option B) Incorrect. Paget's disease is primarily characterised by eczematous changes around the nipple, not by breast swelling or redness.

Option C) Correct. Inflammatory breast cancer is characterised by rapid onset of erythema, warmth, and edema, often without a palpable mass. The hallmark is the involvement of the dermal lymphatics, causing the peau d'orange appearance.

Option D) Incorrect. Phyllodes tumor is a rare breast tumor that typically presents as a fast-growing palpable mass without inflammatory symptoms.

Key Points:

Rapid onset of inflammatory symptoms is the hallmark of IBC.Sentinel lymph node biopsy is not indicated; axillary lymph node dissection is the standard.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 58, Pages 934

questions.text: A 23 year old female comes to gynecology OPD with primary infertility. She has regular menses but there is unbearable pain associated with menses. The patient also complains of painful passage of stools. Later on in the course of treatment, laparoscopy was done for the patient. Following is the image. What is incorrect about the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
Endometriosis

  • Functional endometriotic tissue present outside the uterus.
  • Common sites : ovary, cul de sac, uterosacral ligaments, broad ligament, fallopian tubes, rectosigmoid colon
  • MC site : ovary → chocolate cyst → endometrioma
  • Clinical feature : triad → infertility, dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. (Option A)
  • Diagnosis : USG
  • IOC : laparoscopy(Option B)
  • a. Powder burn lesions, red lesions, blue cystic areas, puckering and fibrosis seen on peritoneum.
  • b. Ovarian mass in form of endometrioma
  • c. Scarring and adhesions

Laparoscopic classification is done using ASRM criteria

Management of endometriosis

  • Laparoscopy is diagnostic as well as therapeutic
  • Androgenic drugs - danazol
  • GnRH agonist - leuprolide, nafarelin
  • GnRH antagonists(Option C)
  • Combined oral contraceptives
  • Gestrinone
  • Mifepristone
  • Infertility is managed by ovulation induction with clomiphene citrate. If there is failure even after three cycles then IVF and ICSI are used for management.
  • For severe disease, IVF is used directly for infertility

Reference : D.C. Dutta textbook of gynecology 7/e, chapter 22, pg 250.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and visual field defects. MRI shows THIS. Laboratory results reveal a prolactin level of 250 µg/L. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
• A. Transsphenoidal surgery: Surgery is not the first-line treatment for prolactinomas unless the patient fails medical therapy or if the tumor is very large and causing significant mass effects unresponsive to medication.
  • B. Dopamine agonists: Dopamine agonists like cabergoline and bromocriptine are the initial treatment of choice for prolactinomas. They reduce prolactin levels, shrink the tumor, and improve symptoms.
  • C. Radiation therapy: Radiation is reserved for cases where surgery and medical therapy have failed or are contraindicated. It is not used as first-line therapy.
  • D. Observation: Observation alone is inappropriate due to the symptoms and elevated prolactin level.

Key Takeaways: Dopamine agonists are the mainstay of treatment for prolactinomas, especially when presenting with symptomatic hyperprolactinemia.

Reference:

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 380, Page 2878.

questions.text: A 26 year old female came to gynecology opd with a complaint of secondary infertility. She has had a past history of abortion at 3 months of gestation followed by dilatation and curettage, she does not have any live issues. HSG was ordered for the patient and the following was seen. What is true for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Ashermann syndrome

  • First described by Joseph Ashermann as amenorrhea traumatica
  • Amenorrhea due to intrauterine synechiae formation
  • M/C/C is curettage in post partum period (surgical abortion)
  • Other causes : C section, myomectomy genital tuberculosis

Genital tuberculosis is cause of ashermann syndrome if there is no history of abortions in past

  • Clinical feature : amenorrhea or hypomenorrhea with infertility
  • Investigation : cobweb appearance in HSG, saline infusion sonography
  • Management : hysteroscopic adhesiolysis with pediatric foley's catheter placement intrauterine

Reference: Dutta's textbook of Gynaecology, 8th edition, chapter 19, Page no: 220

Overview
