  • Increased respiration
  • Hypertension
  • Nausea
  • Decreased appetite
  • Salivation
  • Sweating
  • Blurred vision

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 4, Page no: 1024.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden chest pain and severe shortness of breath after being involved in a road traffic accident. On examination, he has tracheal deviation to the left, hyperresonance on the right side, and absent breath sounds on the right. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Tension Pneumothorax:

Pathophysiology:

  • Mechanism: Air enters the pleural space during inspiration but cannot escape during expiration, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure.
  • Complications: This pressure shift compresses the lung and mediastinal structures, leading to decreased venous return, reduced cardiac output, and potential cardiovascular collapse.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms: Sudden onset of chest pain and severe dyspnea.
  • Signs: Tracheal deviation away from the affected side, hyperresonance to percussion, absent breath sounds on the affected side, and distended neck veins.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Diagnosis: Based on physical examination findings; should not delay treatment.
  • Imaging: While a chest X-ray can confirm the diagnosis, it is not required before initiating emergency treatment.

Management:

  • Immediate Needle Decompression: Insert a large bore needle (14-16 gauge) into the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line of the affected side to relieve pressure.
  • Chest Tube Insertion: Following needle decompression, a chest tube should be placed to allow continuous evacuation of air and reexpansion of the lung.

Option A: Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency, and immediate needle decompression is necessary to relieve the pressure.

Option B: Although a chest Xray can confirm the diagnosis, it is not the first step in a life threatening emergency.

Option C: Oxygen therapy can help in improving low saturation but will not resolve the underlying tension pneumothorax.

Option D: Antibiotics are not indicated in the immediate management of tension pneumothorax.

Key Takeaways:

  • Tension pneumothorax is a life threatening emergency requiring immediate needle decompression to prevent cardiovascular collapse.
  • Rapid recognition and intervention are critical, with chest tube placement following initial decompression.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter -29 , page no: 374

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with acute abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal distension. A CT scan reveals a "whirl sign" in the right lower quadrant. What is the next appropriate management step?
questions.solution:
Volvulus

Twisting of the intestine and its mesentery, most commonly in the sigmoid colon but can occur in the caecum or transverse colon.

  • Common Locations: Caecal Volvulus: Usually affects younger, otherwise healthy individuals.
  • Predisposing Factors: Adhesions, gastric banding, pelvic masses, and pregnancy.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Massive abdominal distension is the key sign. Pain indicates possible ischaemia.
  • Investigation:
    • Supine abdominal radiograph (helpful but not always diagnostic).
    • CT scan is the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Caecal Volvulus: Urgent right hemicolectomy; endoscopic decompression is usually ineffective.

Key points:

  • Cecal volvulus is a surgical emergency that typically requires laparotomy to correct the twisted bowel and prevent complications like bowel ischemia or perforation.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 77, page no: 1273.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with unilateral cafe-au-lait spots, recurrent fractures, and x-ray in her legs shows this. She also has a history of early puberty. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. McCune-Albright syndrome (MAS) is a genetic disorder characterized by a triad of findings: polyostotic fibrous dysplasia (abnormal fibrous tissue replacing normal bone), café-au-lait spots, and endocrine abnormalities such as precocious puberty or hyperthyroidism.
  2. Fibrous dysplasia, a component of MAS, leads to irregular bone growth and recurrent fractures, commonly affecting the long bones, ribs, and skull.
  3. Café-au-lait spots are typically unilateral and have an irregular "coast of Maine" border, which is a distinguishing feature.
  4. Early puberty is a hallmark of MAS due to its effects on endocrine function.

Incorrect Options:

  • Achondroplasia: This condition results in short stature due to defects in cartilage formation, but does not present with café-au-lait spots or precocious puberty.
  • Fibrous dysplasia: While fibrous dysplasia is a key feature of MAS, it alone does not explain the endocrine abnormalities or café-au-lait spots seen in MAS.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta: This condition is characterized by brittle bones and frequent fractures but is not associated with café-au-lait spots or early puberty.

Key Takeaways:

  • McCune-Albright syndrome includes a combination of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, café-au-lait spots, and precocious puberty or other endocrine dysfunctions.
  • Fibrous dysplasia alone lacks the systemic endocrine features and skin manifestations seen in MAS.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 412 (Paget's Disease and Other Dysplasias of Bone, Page no: 3209.

questions.text: You are on call in the emergency department when suddenly you hear the code bell. You rush to the room to find a new arrival, Ms. M. She is a 19-year-old who was out for a jog with a friend when she suddenly and inexplicably passed out. On your arrival, she is unresponsive and pulseless. A 12-lead electrocardiogram is shown in Figure. Which of the following rhythms is the cause of her cardiac arrest?
questions.solution:
1. Understanding Pre-excited Atrial Fibrillation (AF):
  • Definition: Pre-excited AF occurs when atrial fibrillation is conducted through an accessory pathway (AP), bypassing the normal atrioventricular (AV) nodal delay.
  • Mechanism:
    • The AP provides a direct route for atrial impulses to reach the ventricles, often faster than conduction through the AV node.
    • In AF, this leads to rapid, irregular ventricular activation because both the AV node and the AP conduct impulses to the ventricles.
  • Risk: Pre-excited AF can result in ventricular fibrillation (VF) if the accessory pathway allows rapid, repetitive conduction, leading to sudden cardiac arrest.
  1. ECG Findings in Pre-excited AF:
  • Irregular, wide-complex QRS: The ECG typically shows a wide QRS complex with an irregular rhythm due to the irregular atrial activity in AF.
  • QRS Morphology: The QRS complexes often look bizarre and vary from beat to beat, reflecting fusion between conduction through the AV node and the AP.
  • No discernible P waves: Atrial activity is chaotic due to fibrillation, and P waves are absent.
  1. Differentiating from Other Options:
  • Atrial Flutter:
    • Atrial flutter is usually a regular rhythm with characteristic "sawtooth" flutter waves in the atria.
    • It does not present with an irregular, wide-complex QRS pattern as seen in this case.
  • Atrioventricular Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia (AVNRT):
    • AVNRT is a narrow-complex tachycardia due to a reentry circuit within or around the AV node.
    • It would not cause a wide, irregular QRS pattern or be life-threatening in the same way.
  • Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia:
    • Monomorphic VT is a regular wide-complex tachycardia with a single QRS morphology throughout.
    • The irregularity in this case and absence of monomorphic QRS complexes make VT unlikely.
  • Possible DD. Torsades de Pointes:
    • Torsades is a polymorphic VT associated with a prolonged QT interval.
    • It has a distinctive "twisting" QRS morphology, which is not typical in this patient's presentation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pre-excited AF is a potentially life-threatening arrhythmia due to rapid conduction through an accessory pathway, leading to ventricular fibrillation risk.
  • ECG in pre-excited AF shows wide-complex, irregular QRS due to fusion between AV nodal and accessory pathway conduction.
  • Immediate cardioversion is needed in unstable patients to prevent progression to cardiac arrest.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 283, page no: 1903.

questions.text: Main worker of this programme is:
questions.solution:
The National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), launched in 2005, aimed to enhance healthcare delivery in rural India. Here are some key features:

  1. Objective: NRHM focused on providing accessible, affordable, and quality healthcare to rural populations, with a special emphasis on maternal and child health, family planning, and prevention and management of communicable and non-communicable diseases.
  2. Service Delivery: The mission aimed to strengthen the primary healthcare infrastructure by upgrading Sub-Centers, Primary Health Centers (PHCs), and Community Health Centers (CHCs), as well as supporting district hospitals.
  3. Human Resources: NRHM emphasized the training and capacity building of healthcare workers, including the recruitment of Auxiliary Nurse Midwives (ANMs), Accredited Social Health Activists (ASHAs), and other health personnel.
  4. Community Participation: A core feature was involving local communities in health planning and decision-making through Village Health and Sanitation Committees (VHSCs) and other local bodies.
  5. Funding: The mission's funding was shared between central and state governments, supporting both infrastructure development and the provision of healthcare services.
  6. Integration with Other Programs: NRHM worked in conjunction with other programs like Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) and the National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (NREGS) to improve health infrastructure and services.
  7. Health Promotion: The mission promoted health education and awareness campaigns, focusing on preventive and promotive health measures to improve community health outcomes.
  8. Infrastructure Improvement: NRHM supported the construction and renovation of health facilities and provided essential medical equipment and supplies.
  9. Monitoring and Evaluation: Regular monitoring and evaluation were integral to NRHM, with mechanisms in place for continuous improvement based on feedback and health service outcomes.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Main worker of this programme is ASHA.

Reference: NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAMS OF INDIA, 12th Edition, J. Kishore, chapter-06, Page no: 117-120.

questions.text: All diseases are included in this programme except
questions.solution:
Yellow fever is not included in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) of India.

The NVBDCP focuses on the prevention and control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Malaria (option A)
  • Filariasis (option B)
  • Dengue
  • Chikungunya
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • Kala-azar (Leishmaniasis) (option D)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Yellow fever, although a vector-borne disease, is not a major public health concern in India and is not covered under the NVBDCP.

Reference: NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAMS OF INDIA, 12th Edition, J. Kishore, chapter-11, Page no: 376-381.

questions.text: Antagonism shown by drug A and B in the following dose-response curve (DRC) is known as?
questions.solution:
• The parallel rightward shift of agonist dose- response curve (DRC) is seen with competitive antagonism.
  • Increasing the dose of the agonist can result in the same maximal response.

Competitive antagonism

  • The antagonist is chemically similar to the agonist, competes with it and binds to the same site of the agonist molecules.
  • Because the antagonist has affinity but no intrinsic activity, no response is produced and the log DRC of the agonist is shifted to the right.

Option B: Noncompetitive antagonism

The antagonist is chemically unrelated to the agonist, binds to a different allosteric site altering the receptor in such a way that it is unable to combine with the agonist or is unable to transduce the response.

Increasing concentrations of the antagonist progressively flatten the agonist

DRC

Option C & D: Physiological/functional antagonism

The two drugs act on different receptors or by different mechanisms, but have opposite overt effects on the same physiological function, i.e. have pharmacological effects in opposite direction, e.g.

  • Histamine and adrenaline on bronchial muscles and on BP.
  • Hydrochlorothiazide and amiloride on urinary K+ excretion.
  • Glucagon and insulin on blood sugar level.

Key takeaway:

  • The parallel rightward shift of agonist dose- response curve (DRC) is seen with competitive antagonism. Increasing the dose of the agonist can result in the same maximal response.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no: 67.

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented to pulmonary department with complaints of malaise, anorexia, weight loss, nocturnal cough and dyspnoea. On examination and investigation her eosinophilic count was elevated with high Ig E levels in serum. Imaging study showed following image with pulmonary infiltration. Which of the following is the drug of choice for tropical pulmonary eosinophilia?
questions.solution:
Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia:

  • DEC (2-4 mg/kg TDS) for 2-3 weeks produces dramatic improvement in the signs and symptoms of eosinophilic lung or tropical eosinophilia.
  • The benefit probably reflects anti-microfilarial action: the symptoms of the disease being presumably due to reaction to the Mf.
  • The associated cough may respond to inhaled corticosteroids.

Key Takeaway:

  • Diethyl carbamazine citrate produces dramatic improvement in the signs and symptoms of eosinophilic lung or tropical eosinophilia.

Topic:

  • Must Know
  • Diethyl carbamazine citrate

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no: 911.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida requires pain relief for the second stage of labor. The obstetrician decides to perform the procedure shown in the image. Which anatomical landmark is used as a guide in this nerve block?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a PUDENDAL NERVE BLOCK and ischial spine is the landmark for pudendal nerve.

OPTION A: Pubic symphysis: It is not used as a landmark for the pudendal nerve block. It is a landmark for different procedures like abdominal incision placement in C-section, Symphysiotomy etc.

OPTION B: Ischial tuberosity: It is not the primary landmark for the pudendal block. The block targets the area near the ischial spine.

OPTION C: Ischial spine: The pudendal nerve block is performed by targeting the area near the ischial spine, which is a key landmark for the procedure.

OPTION D: Sacral promontory: It is used as a landmark for other procedures like laparoscopic pelvic surgeries, sacral nerve stimulation etc. but not for the pudendal nerve block.

Type: Must know

Topic: Obstetric analgesia

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Page no: 1206-1207

questions.text: A patient came to emergency ward with a history of RTA. He was drowsy during the examination. On eliciting the history it was found that after the accident he was drowsy and had a few minutes of consciousness before entering the hospital. On the basis of this history, it was decided to do a CT scan of the head which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Location: An epidural hematoma occurs between the inner table of the skull and the outer periosteal layer of the dura mater.
  • Appearance: It typically has a convex (lens-shaped) appearance on CT scans. This convexity results from the tight adherence of the periosteal dura to the skull, which prevents the hematoma from spreading into the subdural space.
  • Association: EDHs are commonly linked with a fracture of the temporal part of the skull and are often caused by injury to the middle meningeal artery.
  • Origin: Because EDHs are generally arterial in origin, they tend to present as hyperdense (bright) areas on unenhanced CT scans due to the higher density of arterial blood compared to venous blood.
  • Symptoms: Patients with EDHs may develop symptoms rapidly due to the arterial nature of the hemorrhage, which can lead to a quick accumulation of blood and increased intracranial pressure.

Option C: Subarachnoid hemorrhage is seen in subarachnoid spaces.

Option A: Subdural hemorrhage is seen in subdural layer

Option D: Intraparenchymal hemorrhage appears within the brain parenchyma

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no: 1398.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe abdominal pain. On doing a USG, the right ovary was found to be normal and the left ovary appeared enlarged and did not show vascularity. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ovarian torsion is the twisting of the ovary around its supporting ligaments, leading to a reduction or complete loss of blood flow to the ovary. It is a gynecological emergency that requires prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent ovarian damage or necrosis.

  1. Causes:
  • Usually associated with an enlarged ovary, often due to ovarian cysts, tumors, or hyperstimulation (as in fertility treatments).
  • Can also occur in normal ovaries, particularly in younger women or during pregnancy.
  1. Symptoms:
  • Sudden onset of severe, sharp pelvic pain (typically unilateral).
  • Nausea and vomiting.
  • Abdominal tenderness, sometimes with a palpable mass.
  1. Diagnosis:
  • Ultrasound with Doppler is commonly used to assess blood flow to the ovary, although normal Doppler findings do not completely exclude torsion.

Doppler usually shows absent vascularity to the ovaries.

  • Clinical presentation is crucial in diagnosis, as imaging may not always be conclusive.
  1. Treatment: Surgical intervention (laparoscopy or laparotomy) to untwist the ovary and restore blood flow. Oophorectomy (removal of the ovary) may be necessary if the ovary is necrotic.
  2. Complications:
  • If untreated, ovarian torsion can lead to loss of the ovary, infertility, and severe infection (peritonitis).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Ovarian torsion is the twisting of the ovary around its supporting ligaments, leading to a reduction or complete loss of blood flow to the ovary.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no: 1879.

choices.text: Can deliver high tidal volumes if activated in inspiration

questions.text: All of the following are the advantages of the given part of the anaesthesia machine except:
questions.solution:
Given image is that of the oxygen flush.

The oxygen flush (oxygen bypass, emergency oxygen bypass) receives oxygen from the pipeline inlet or cylinder pressure regulator and directs a high unmetered flow directly to the common gas outlet. It is commonly labeled "O2+".

  • It is a self closing device, operable with one hand, and designed to minimise unintentional activation. (option A and B)
  • Oxygen flush activation during inspiration delivered by the anesthesia ventilator will result in delivery of high tidal volumes and possible barotrauma.

Key takeaway: Oxygen flush activation during inspiration delivered by the anesthesia ventilator will result in delivery of high tidal volumes and possible barotrauma.

Tags:

Topic: Anesthesia Machine

Difficulty level: Easy

Reference: Understanding Anaesthesia Equipment (Jerry A. Dorsch, Susan E. Dorsch) 5th edition pg 101.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy presented with limp and pain in right hip which often radiated to knee and walks with Trendelenburg gait. There is faint history of mild trauma before 10 days. The xray is as follows. Which movement will be specifically restricted in this case :
questions.solution:
The condition in the case given is Legg-Calve-Perthes; disease.

Perthes Disease

  • Clinical Features:
    • Noninflammatory deformity of the proximal femur due to a vascular insult of unknown origin, leading to osteonecrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis.
    • Pathology: Osteonecrosis is followed by revascularization and resorption through creeping substitution, which eventually allows remodeling.
    • Most common in boys aged 4-8 years with delayed skeletal maturation who are very active.
    • Increased incidence associated with a positive family history, low birth weight, and abnormal birth presentation (often linked with delayed bone age and ADHD).
    • Symptoms:
      • Pain (often referred to the knee).
      • Effusion from synovitis.
      • Limp.
      • Decreased hip range of motion (ROM), especially in abduction and internal rotation. (Options A,B,C and D)
      • Trendelenburg gait is common.
    • Bilateral Involvement:
      • Seen in 12%-15% of cases, typically not simultaneous.
      • May mimic multiple epiphyseal dysplasia (MED); a skeletal survey is warranted in these cases.
    • Differential Diagnosis:
      • Septic arthritis, blood dyscrasias, hypothyroidism, epiphyseal dysplasia.
  • Examination Findings:
    • Pain in the hip, often radiating to the knee.
    • Limping or hip stiffness.
    • Limited abduction and internal rotation.
    • Shortening of the affected limb.
    • Radiological Findings:
      • Collapse and sclerosis of the femoral head epiphysis.
      • Increased hip joint space.
  • Goals of Treatment:
    • Relief of symptoms.
    • Restoration of range of motion (ROM).
    • Containment of the hip.
  • Non-Surgical Treatment:
    • Outpatient or inpatient traction.
    • Anti-inflammatory medications.
    • Partial weight-bearing with crutches for periods ranging from 1–2 days to several weeks.
    • Maintaining ROM:
      • Traction, muscle release, exercises, Petrie cast, or a combination of these methods.
  • Surgical Treatment:
    • Herring's treatment plan is based on age and the lateral pillar classification.
    • Surgical treatment may improve radiographic outcomes at skeletal maturity for older patients (chronologic age >8 years or bone age >6 years) with lateral pillar groups B and B/C hips.
    • Containment Procedures:
      • Femoral Osteotomy: Proximal femoral varus osteotomy.
      • Pelvic Osteotomy: Salter, triple, Dega, Pemberton.
      • Shelf Osteotomy: Prevents lateral subluxation and lateral epiphyseal overgrowth.
    • Salvage Procedures:
      • Valgus Femoral Osteotomy: For hinge abduction.
      • Chiari and/or Shelf Pelvic Osteotomies: For hips that can no longer be contained.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 318.

questions.text:
A patient with symptoms of urethritis has a Gram stain image showing Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes.

Which bacterium is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
• Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a Gram-negative diplococcus bacterium within polymorphonuclear leukocytes.
  • Causes urethral discharge, dysuria, itching or irritation in urethra.
  • If untreated, it can lead to epididymitis, prostatitis, or infertility in men.
  • In women, it may lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which can result in infertility.

A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Gram-negative diplococci, often seen inside leukocytes.

B) Neisseria meningitidis: Also Gram-negative diplococci, but primarily associated with meningitis, not urethritis.

C) Haemophilus influenzae: Gram-negative coccobacilli, not diplococci.

D) Treponema pallidum: Spirochete bacteria, not Gram-negative diplococci.

Key Takeaway: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is identified by Gram-negative diplococci, particularly in cases of gonorrheal infections.

Reference: CDC Neisseria gonorrhoeae

questions.text: Look at the image below showing a skin lesion. Which parasite is most likely causing this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a skin lesion with ulcerative lesions and potential nodules, commonly found on exposed skin areas.

Leishmania braziliensis is a protozoan parasite that causes mucocutaneous leishmaniasis.

  • Transmitted to humans through the bite of infected Phlebotomine sandflies, primarily Lutzomyia species.
  • Reservoir hosts include wild animals like rodents and small mammals.

Explanation:

  • A) Onchocerca volvulus: Causes river blindness with skin symptoms, but typically shows more generalized skin changes and not localized ulcers.
  • B) Leishmania braziliensis: The image depicts cutaneous leishmaniasis, characterized by skin ulcers and nodules. This species is known for causing skin lesions, including the leishmaniasis ulcers.
  • C) Sarcoptes scabiei: Causes scabies, which results in itchy skin rashes and burrows rather than ulcerative lesions.
  • D) Ancylostoma duodenale: A hookworm that affects the intestines and not usually associated with skin ulcers.

Key Takeaway: Leishmania braziliensis is identified by skin ulcers and nodules, commonly associated with cutaneous leishmaniasis.

Reference: For more information on Leishmania braziliensis and its skin manifestations, refer to the CDC's leishmaniasis resources: CDC - Leishmaniasis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old patient with a history of chronic sinusitis presents with sinus pain and nasal discharge. The biopsy image shows septate hyphae with acute-angle branching.


What fungal infection does the biopsy most likely indicate?
questions.solution:
A-Acute angled branching

Sp-Septate

Explanation:

Option A) Aspergillosis: Characterized by septate hyphae with acute-angle branching, typical of Aspergillus species.

Option B) Candidiasis: Shows yeast cells and pseudohyphae, not hyphae with acute-angle branching.

Option C) Blastomycosis: Features broad-based budding yeast cells.

Option D) Sporotrichosis: Shows cigar-shaped yeast cells with branching hyphae.

Key Takeaway: Aspergillosis is identified by its distinct hyphal structure with acute-angle branching.

Reference: CDC Aspergillosis Overview

questions.text: Above image shows Glucose Tolerance test curves. If Urine Sugar is ++ (Present) at 1 hour after 75 gm of Glucose Load in Patient #1, what is your probable Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• As shown in above image, three different Glucose Tolerance test curves signify three different conditions,
  • Glucose tolerance test is done for Diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus, Impaired Glucose Tolerance or pathological causes leading to glucose intolerance in body.
  • Glucose tolerance is the ability to regulate the blood glucose concentration after the administration of a test dose of glucose (normally 1 g/kg body weight) The normal glucose tolerance is determine by the timing of and quantity of insulin secreted and the ability of tissues to respond to insulin.
  • Impaired glucose tolerance seen in liver damage, some infections, and in response to some drugs, hyperactivity of the pituitary gland etc.
  • Glucose is continuously filtered by glomeruli but it actively reabsorbs back from renal tubule & capacity is upto rate of 2mmol/min (350mg/min). Renal Threshold for glucose is Blood Glucose value 180mg/dl. In excess of Blood Glucose level, Glycosuria (presence of Glucose in urine) appears. But in some pathological conditions / renal conditions
  • where renal threshold is lowered leading to presence of Glucose in urine at much lower level of Blood Glucose leading to Pathological Glycosuria.

As in above case history, after Glucose load, in patient #1 although blood sugar value at 0 hour, 1 hour and 2hours are within normal range. But presence of Urine sugar at 1 hour that is more likely suggestive of Renal Glycosuria - Pathological.

Clinical Significance of Glucose Tolerance Test:

  • Normal Glucose Tolerance: Fasting Blood Sugar at 0 hr < 100, Post 2 hr <140
  • Impaired Glucose Tolerance: Fasting Blood Sugar at 0 hrs between 100-125, Post 02 hr between 140-1200
  • Impaired fasting Blood Glucose; Fasting Blood Sugar at 0 hrs between 100-125 rest are normal
  • Diabetes Mellitus: Fasting Blood Sugar at 0 hrs is ≥ 126, Post 2 hour ≥200

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter 19, page 189

questions.text: Below image shows characteristic sign of vitamin deficiency due to possible causes
questions.solution:
Above image shows classical sign of Vitamin B3 (Niacin) Deficiency - Casal's Necklace seen in Pellagra along with Diarrhea and dementia.

Option B) Hartnup disease is a rare genetic condition in which there is a defect of the membrane transport mechanism for tryptophan, resulting in large losses as

a result of intestinal malabsorption and failure of renal reabsorption.

Option A) In carcinoid syndrome, there is metastasis of a primary liver tumor of enterochromaffin cells, which synthesize 5-hydroxytryptamine. Overproduction of 5-hydroxytryptamine may account for as much as 60% of the body's tryptophan metabolism, causing pellagra because of the diversion away from NAD synthesis

Option C) 60 mg of Tryptophan is equivalent to 1 mg Niacin, conversion requires riboflavin or vitamin B6. so in tryptophan deficiency can also lead to Niacin Deficiency and Pellagra.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, Chap 44, page no. 543

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman experienced increasing malaise and a 10-kg weight loss in the last year of her life. She has been increasingly obtunded, lapsed into a coma, and died. At autopsy, the liver has the gross appearance shown in the figure. Ingestion of which of the following substances is most likely to have played a role in the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
A. Aflatoxin is a hepatotoxin and is the product of the fungus Aspergillus flavus, which grows on moldy cereals.

  • Aflatoxin can be carcinogenic, leading to hepatocellular carcinoma, as shown in the figure.

Incorrect Options:

B. Oysters can concentrate HAV from seawater contaminated with sewage, and eating raw oysters can result in HAV infection.

C. Aspirin has been implicated in causing Reye syndrome in children, which results in extensive micro vesicular steatosis.

D. Nitrites have been causally linked with cancers in the upper gastrointestinal tract.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Aflatoxin is a hepatotoxin and is the product of the fungus Aspergillus flavus, which grows on moldy cereals.

Aflatoxin can be carcinogenic, leading to hepatocellular carcinoma

Reference: Robbins & Cotran, 10th edition, page no. 869.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with Alzheimer disease dies of pneumonia. The gross appearance of the right kidney at autopsy is shown in the figure. The left kidney is normal in size, with a smooth cortical surface and a single 0.6-cm, fluid-filled cyst. The appearance of the right kidney is most suggestive of renal injury from which of the following?
questions.solution:
The ureteral, pelvic, and calyceal dilation results from long-standing obstruction leading to hydroureter and hydronephrosis.

Ureteral obstruction can cause hydronephrosis and hydroureter because it prevents urine from flowing properly in the urinary tract:

  • Hydronephrosis

This condition occurs when the renal pelvis and calyces swell due to urine building up in the kidneys. It can be caused by a number of things, including kidney stones, tumors, and blood clots.

  • Hydroureter

This condition occurs when the ureter dilates. It can be caused by a urethral valve obstruction, or by prolonged preservation of the ureteric membrane.

Ureteral obstruction can have serious consequences, including:

  • Permanent kidney damage: If left untreated, kidney damage can become permanent and difficult to reverse.
  • Renal failure: Long-standing hydronephrosis can lead to renal failure.
  • Urinary tract infections: Urinary stasis from a blockage can increase the risk of infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - With benign nephrosclerosis, the kidneys become smaller and develop granular surfaces, but there is no dilation.

Option C & D - The scarring that accompanies analgesic nephropathy or chronic pyelonephritis can be marked; it is associated with significant loss of renal parenchyma, but not with pelvic dilation.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran, 10th edition, page no. 946.

questions.text: A patient developed the following lesions after 10 days of treatment. Patient also complains of similar lesions over soles and they are sensitive to touch. Which of the following is the most likely agent responsible for development of that adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• The given image depicts classical findings of hand foot syndrome and capecitabine is commonly associated with this prominent side effect.
  • Hand foot syndrome or palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia consists of erythema, desquamation, pain and sensitivity to touch of the palms and soles.

Drugs commonly implicated are:

  • Capecitabine
  • 5-Fluorouracil
  • Cytarabine
  • Pemetrexed
  • Doxorubicin

Option A: Cisplatin is associated with nausea and vomiting (maximum among all anti-cancer drugs). It is mild bone marrow suppressants and are nephrotoxic, ototoxic as well as neurotoxic.

Option B: Vincristine is associated with development of peripheral neuropathy in first few weeks of therapy characterised by paraesthesia and loss of reflexes

Option D: Mitomycin C is associated with bone marrow and g.i.t. are the primary targets of toxicity. Myelosuppression is typically delayed. A haemolytic-uremic syndrome is reported.

Key takeaway:

  • Capecitabine is associated with Hand foot syndrome or palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia

Tags:

  • Must Know
  • Capecitabine

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 923

questions.text: Identify the unknown drug A by its action on rabbit ileum in the given image below:
questions.solution:
• The given figure shows that the drug is stimulant at rabbit ileum and its stimulatory effects are not blocked by atropine.
  • So, it seems to be a directly acting stimulant like Barium chloride or calcium chloride. We can identify the nature of some drugs by their effect on rabbit ileum
  • To identify the unknown drug, First see whether the drug increases the tone (stimulant) or decreases (depressant).
  • If it is stimulant, it is likely to be acetylcholine or barium chloride. Then see, whether the effect can be abolished by atropine or not. If stimulant effect is absent after atropine, the drug is acetylcholine but if it is still present, then it is directly acting drug like barium or calcium chloride.
  • If it is depressant, it is likely to be adrenaline or papaverine. Then see, whether the effect can be abolished by betablocker or not. If depressant effect is absent or reduced after giving beta blocker (completely abolished by alpha plus beta blocker), the drug is adrenaline but if it is still present, then it is directly acting drug like papaverine or KCl.

Key takeaway:

  • Barium chloride or calcium chloride drug is stimulant at rabbit ileum and its stimulatory effects are not blocked by atropine.

Tags:

  • Good to Know
  • Barium chloride

Reference: Fundamentals of experimental pharmacology by M.N. Ghosh, 6th edition, page no. 99

questions.text: Examination of a suspicious stain shows the following finding. The test is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Barberios test:

  • The Barberios test is used for the detection of semen and is characterized by the formation of yellow, needle-shaped crystals when a stain is treated with certain reagents. This test is specific for identifying seminal fluid.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B - Florence test: The Florence test detects the presence of blood by forming yellow, needle-shaped crystals. However, in practice, it's often referred to as the Florence Reaction, which is not commonly used to identify semen.
  • Option C - Teichman test: The Teichman test is also used for blood detection but is characterized by the formation of rhomboid-shaped crystals, not needle-shaped ones.
  • Option D - Takayama test: The Takayama test detects blood and forms pink or reddish-brown crystals, not yellow needle-shaped crystals.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The Barberios test is used for the detection of semen and is characterized by the formation of yellow, needle-shaped crystals when a stain is treated with certain reagents. This test is specific for identifying seminal fluid.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 434

questions.text: A 22 year old G2POA1 woman presents to casualty with complaints of amenorrhoea since 2 months, acute abdominal pain & slight bleeding. On per vaginal examination, cervical motion tenderness was classically found. UPT was done & found to be positive. Urgent USG was ordered for & showed the following pattern on Doppler. Which is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
OPTION B: The classic triad of ectopic pregnancy is delayed menstruation, pain, and vaginal bleeding or spotting. Placental blood flow within the periphery of the complex adnexal mass-the ring of fire-can be seen with transvaginal color Doppler imaging (as shown in the figure).

OPTION A: While acute PID can cause abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, and vaginal bleeding, it would not typically present with a positive urine pregnancy test (UPT). Additionally, the "ring of fire" pattern is not a feature of PID; this pattern indicates increased blood flow around an ectopic gestational sac.

OPTION C: Pregnancy of unknown location: This term is used when a pregnancy is confirmed (positive UPT) but the location is not yet determined. But since the G-sac is localized and the "ring of fire" pattern on Doppler is present, it is more specific to ectopic pregnancy.

OPTION D: Dermoid cyst is a type of ovarian cyst that can contain various types of tissues from all 3 germ layers. It is not typically associated with the "ring of fire" pattern or with the acute symptoms described.

Tags:

  • Type: Must know
  • Topic: Ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: Most common cause of bilateral cornual block on HSG:
questions.solution:
OPTION C: Physiological spasm of the uterotubal junction during the procedure is the most common cause of bilateral cornual block on HSG. This spasm is transient and can be relieved with antispasmodic agents, showing normal tube patency on repeat HSG.

OPTION A: Gonococcal infection can cause pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) leading to scarring and blockage of the fallopian tubes. However, it usually causes a more irregular, dilated tubal appearance rather than a cornual block on HSG.

OPTION B: Tuberculosis of the genital tract can cause bilateral tubal blockage, often with beading or clubbing of the tubes. While TB can cause cornual block, it is not the most common cause and usually presents with additional findings such as endometrial calcifications.

OPTION D: Asherman's syndrome involves intrauterine adhesions, which can lead to blockage, but it typically affects the uterine cavity rather than causing a cornual block of the fallopian tubes specifically.

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no. 508-509

questions.text: Which manoeuvre is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
For delivering the aftercoming head in a breech delivery, the Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit maneuver is typically used.

OPTION A) Ritgen's maneuver

This maneuver is used to assist in the delivery of the fetal head during a vertex presentation by applying pressure to the perineum and the fetal head to facilitate its descent.

OPTION B) McRoberts maneuver

This maneuver involves flexing the mother's legs tightly against her abdomen to alleviate shoulder dystocia during a vertex presentation.

OPTION C) Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit maneuver

This maneuver is specifically designed for delivering the aftercoming head in a breech delivery. It involves using the fingers to flex the fetal neck and applying gentle traction to the head.

OPTION D) Woods corkscrew maneuver

This maneuver is used to manage shoulder dystocia during a vertex delivery by rotating the fetal shoulders to free the impacted shoulder.

Tags:

  • Type: Must know
  • Topic: Assisted breech delivery

Reference: Dutta's Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no. 445

questions.text: A 12-year old male presented with asymptomatic erythematous scaly lesions over back. There was history of sore throat. There were collarette scales in erythematous lesions. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pityriasis rosea is self-limiting.
  • Flu-like symptoms a few days before the rash appears. First lesion is characterized by a large circular or oval "herald patch", usually found on the chest, abdomen, or back.
  • The herald patch is followed by the development of smaller scaly oval red patches, resembling a Christmas tree, distributed mainly on the chest and back.
  • Collarette scale is characteristic sign in pityriasis rosea. With edge peripherally attached and lifted up near the centre of lesion.

Option B - Pityriasis rubra pilaris Scaly (Pityriasis)

  • Pink to orange (Rubra)
  • Follicular papules (pilaris)
  • Grouped papules frequently coalesce to form large plaques
  • typically with distinct islands of normal skin
  • islands of normal skin are often studded with erythematous follicular scaly papules
  • Palm and sole are commonly involved with orange red waxy keratoderma.

Option C - Pityriasis versicolor is a superficial fungal infection.

  • There are hypo or hyperpigmented mildly scaly macules over neck, upper chest, upper back.
  • Causative agent is Malasezzia globosa/ M. furfur
  • On KOH mount - Yeast and hyphae are seen known as 'spaghetti and meatball appearance'
  • On woods lamp: Pale yellow fluorescence

Option D - Guttate psoriasis

  • It is a variant of psoriasis that is classically triggered by streptococcal infection (pharyngitis or perianal)
  • more common in children and adolescents than adults.
  • Manifests as numerous, small, scattered papules and plaques. These are often referred to as "drop-like" and typically manifest as 2 to 6 mm papules.

Tag: Pityriasis rosea

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no 25.90, 25.91

questions.text: Identify the splint and choose correct option according to its indication:
questions.solution:
The image shown is of Bohler-Brown splint.

Bohler-Braun splint: It has a number of pulleys (1-3) over which the traction cord passes while giving skeletal traction for different fractures. It is more convenient than Thomas splint since it has no ring. The ring of a Thomas splint is a common cause of discomfort, especially in elderly people. A Bohler-Braun splint has no inbuilt system of countertraction, hence it is not suitable for transportation.

Fig: Bohler Braun Splint

Option A: It is one of the commonest splints used in orthopaedic practice. It was devised by H.O. Thomas, initially for immobilisation for tuberculosis of the knee. It is now commonly used for the immobilisation and transportation of hip and thigh injuries.

Fig. Thomas splint

Option D: Cramer-wire splint: This splint is used for temporary splintage of fractures during transportation. It is made up of two thick parallel wires with interlacing wires. It can be bent into different shapes in order to immobilise different parts of the body.

questions.text: Choose the most common type of vertebral TB from the image given below:
questions.solution:
Option A. shows paradiscal type of involvement (on either side of IV disc) and is the most common type

Pathology of Spinal Tuberculosis

  • Overview:
    • Spinal tuberculosis is secondary to tuberculosis in other body parts.
    • Bacteria reach the spine via the haematogenous route from the lungs or lymph nodes.
    • Spread occurs via Batson's plexus (para-vertebral plexus), which communicates with the visceral plexus of the abdomen, a common site of tuberculosis.
  • Types of Vertebral Tuberculosis:
    • Paradiscal:
      • Most common type.
      • Affects contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae and the intervening disc.
    • Central:
      • Affects the body of a single vertebra.
      • Leads to early collapse of the weakened vertebra.
      • Nearby disc may be normal.
      • Collapse may be in the form of 'wedging' or 'concertina'; wedging is more common.
    • Anterior:
      • Infection localized to the anterior part of the vertebral body.
      • Infection spreads up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament.
      • It is the most common in children
    • Posterior:
      • Affects the posterior complex of the vertebra (pedicle, lamina, spinous process, transverse process).

Reference: J. Maheshwari's, 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics, page no. 186.

questions.text: Identify the test used during psychiatric interview
questions.solution:
Option A: Standard progressive matrices

  • The Standard Progressive Matrices (SPM) is a non-verbal intelligence test measuring abstract reasoning and cognitive ability.
  • It consists of visual patterns with missing elements that the participant must complete.
  • The test assesses general intelligence, particularly fluid intelligence, independent of language or cultural background.

Option B: Bender Gestalt test

  • The Bender Gestalt Test is a psychological assessment used to evaluate visual-motor functioning and cognitive processing.
  • It involves copying geometric figures to assess perception, coordination, and potential neurological or psychological issues, often used in diagnosing brain disorders or developmental delays.

Option C: Vineland social maturity scale

  • The Vineland Social Maturity Scale is an assessment tool used to measure an individual's social competence and adaptive behavior.
  • It evaluates the ability to perform daily life tasks, such as communication, self-care, social interactions, and academic skills.
  • Primarily used for children and individuals with developmental disabilities, it helps guide educational and therapeutic interventions.

Option D: Binet Kamath test

  • The Binet-Kamath Test is an adaptation of the Binet-Simon intelligence scale, designed to assess the cognitive abilities of children.
  • It evaluates various aspects of intelligence, including memory, reasoning, and problem-solving, through age-appropriate tasks to measure mental age and intellectual development.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 1, Pages 274

questions.text: Which scientist gave this model?
questions.solution:
Option A: Sigmund Freud

  • Sigmund Freud's topographical model of the mind divides it into three levels: the conscious, preconscious, and unconscious.
  • The consciousness contains thoughts and perceptions we are currently aware of.
  • The preconscious includes memories and information that can be easily accessed.
  • The unconscious holds repressed desires, memories, and unresolved conflicts that influence our behavior and thoughts without us being aware of them, often manifesting through dreams and slips of the tongue.

Option B: Carl Jung

  • Carl Jung's model of the mind includes both the conscious and unconscious.
  • The conscious mind consists of thoughts, perceptions, and awareness in the present moment.
  • The personal unconscious holds repressed memories, forgotten information, and unresolved experiences unique to the individual.
  • The collective unconscious, a key concept in Jung's theory, contains archetypes-universal symbols and patterns of behavior shared across humanity, influencing dreams, myths, and cultural expressions, shaping individual and collective experiences.

Option C: Abraham Maslow

  • Abraham Maslow's hierarchy of needs is a psychological theory that organizes human motivations into five levels.
  • At the base are physiological needs, followed by safety, love and belonging, esteem, and finally, self-actualization at the top.
  • Maslow proposed that individuals must satisfy lower-level needs before progressing to higher ones, with self-actualization representing the fulfillment of personal potential and creativity, the ultimate goal of human motivation.

Option D: Jean Piaget

  • Jean Piaget, a Swiss psychologist, made significant contributions to psychiatry by developing a theory of cognitive development.
  • He identified four stages-sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational, and formal operational-demonstrating how children's thinking evolves.
  • Piaget's work influenced understanding of intellectual growth, child psychology, and the development of educational and therapeutic practices in psychiatry.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 34, Pages 3400

questions.text: Image shows lines corresponding to the iliac crests that are palpated while giving spinal anaesthesia. The line connecting the highest points of the two iliac crests is called the tuffier's line. Tuffier's line passes through _______ vertebral body

questions.text: A 24 year old woman presents with a fluctuant non-tender swelling at the introitus. On examination the swelling is visualised as given in the image. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The above given image is of bartholin's cyst

OPTION A: Marsupialization is the preferred treatment for a Bartholin's cyst, especially if it's recurrent or symptomatic. This procedure involves creating a permanent opening to facilitate continuous drainage, reducing the risk of recurrence.

OPTION B Incision & Drainage is generally used for acutely infected Bartholin's abscess rather than a cyst. This method may provide temporary relief but has a high recurrence rate and is not ideal for cyst management.

OPTION C: Aspiration is rarely used for Bartholin's cyst as it often results in recurrence due to incomplete drainage and closure of the cyst's duct. It is not a definitive treatment.

OPTION D: Surgical Resection of the Bartholin gland is a more invasive option and is typically reserved for cases where other treatments have failed or if there is suspicion of malignancy. It is not the first-line treatment due to its associated risks and complications.

Key takeaway: Marsupialization offers a balance between effective, less invasive management and a lower recurrence rate, making it the best choice for symptomatic Bartholin's cyst.

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 320

questions.text: A-patient with previous history of abdominal surgery comes to hospital with abdominal pain and fever. X-ray of abdomen is shown below. This corresponds to
questions.solution:
The patient need not prove negligence in case where the rule of "res ipsa loquitur" applies, which means ''the thin or facts speaks for itself'.

The patient has to merely state what according to him was the act of negligence. Conditions to be satisfied:

  1. that in the absence of negligence, the injury would not have occurred ordinarily;
  2. that the doctor had exclusive control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment;
  3. that the patient was not guilty of contributory negligence. This enables the patient's lawyer to prove his case without medical evidence.

Option B: Res judicata, i.e., if a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court, the patient cannot contest the same in another proceeding on the same set of facts. Only appeal can be made. Limitation: A case should be filed within 2 years from the date of alleged negligence. Where breach of duty to provide care as per a contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action can be initiated up to 3 years from the date of alleged negligence

Option C: NOVUS ACTUS INTERVENIENS: A person is responsible not only for his actions, but also for the logical consequences of those actions. This principle applies to cases of assault and accidental injury. Sometimes, such a continuity of events is broken by an entirely new and unexpected happening due to negligence of some other person. In such cases, the assailant will not be fully responsible for the ultimate harm.

Option D: VICARIOUS LIABILITY: (Liability for act of another): An employer is responsible not only for his own negligence, but also for the negligence of his employees, if such acts occur in the course of the employment and within its scope, by the principle of respondent superior (let the master answer).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Res Ipsa Loquitor - Facts speak for themselves.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 38

questions.text: Postmortem marbling becomes prominent at what time?
questions.solution:
The given picture shows postmortem marbling. It starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

  • The blood in the vessels is haemolysed, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance.
  • It is greenish-brown or purplish-red discoloration of superficial veins due to the formation of sulf methemoglobin, which diffuses into tissues.
  • It is distinctly appreciable on the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Options A,B and D are incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Postmortem marbling, starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

TAGLINE-EASY

questions.text: Cells seen in given image are typically seen in which of the following conditions?

Mott cells are a type of plasma cell that is characteristically seen in multiple myeloma.

Mott cells are a type of abnormal plasma cell characterized by the accumulation of immunoglobulins (antibodies) in the form of Russell bodies within their cytoplasm.

Appearance: Plasma cells with grape-like clusters of immunoglobulin-filled inclusions (Russell bodies).

  • They are less commonly seen in other conditions, such as monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) or plasmacytoma

questions.text: The image below shows Uptake of various substances during the 0.75 s they are in transit through a pulmonary capillary. Here the Transport of N2O is
questions.solution:
• Option B- Nitrous oxide (N2O) does not react and reaches equilibrium in about 0.1 s. The amount of N2O taken up is not limited by diffusion but by the amount of blood flowing through the pulmonary capillaries; that is, it is flow-limited.
  • Option C - Carbon monoxide (CO) is taken up by hemoglobin in the red blood cells at such a high rate that the partial pressure of CO in the capillaries stays very low and equilibrium is not reached in the 0.75 s the blood is in the pulmonary capillaries. So, the CO transfer is diffusion limited.
  • Option A - Oxygen (O2) it is taken up by hemoglobin, but much less avidly than CO, and it reaches equilibrium with capillary blood in about 0.3 s. Thus, its uptake is perfusion limited.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no.1447
